characters: MARY IN NEW CAR ON ROUTE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Above Midtown section of the city. It is early afternoon, hot mid-summer day. The city is sun-sunblanched white and its drifted-up noises are muted in blanched their own ech We fly low, heading in a downtown direction, passing over traffic-clogged streets, parking lots, white business  buildings, neatly patterned residential districts. As we  approach downtown section, the character of the city begi to change. It is darker and shabby with age and industry. see railroad tracks, smokestacks, wholesale fruit-and- vegetable markets, old municipal buildings, empty lots.   vegetable The very geography seems to give us a climate o nefariousness, of back-doorness, dark and shadowy. And se We fly lower and faster now, as if seeking out a specific location. A skinny, high old hotel comes into view. On it exposed brick side great painted letters advertise "Trans Low Weekly Rates-Radio in Every Room." We pause long enou to establish the shoddy character of this hotel. Its open curtainless windows, its silent resigned look so  characteristic of such hole-and-corner hotels. We move fo with purposefulness and-toward a certain window. The sash raised as high as it can go, but the shade is pulled down three or four inches of the inside sill, as if the occupa of the room within wanted privacy but needed air. We are  close now, so that only the lower half of the window fram is in shot. No sounds come from within the room. Suddenly, we tip downward, go to the narrow space between shade and sill, peep into the room. A young woman is stretched out on the mussed bed. She wea a full slip, stockings, no shoes. She lies in and attitud of physical relaxation, but her face, seen in the dimness the room, betrays a certain inner-tension, worrisome  conflicts. She is MARY CRANE, an tension, attractive girl nearing the end of her twenties and her rope. A man stands beside the bed, only the lower half of his f visible. We hold on this tableau for a long moment, then  start forward. As we pass under the window shade,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small room, a slow fan buzzing on a shelf above the nar bed. A card of hotel rules is pasted on the mirror above bureau. An unopened suitcase and a woman's large, straw o top handbag are on the bureau. On the table beside the bed there are a container of Coco Cola and an unwrapped, untouched egg-salad sandwich. Ther is no radio. The man standing by the bed, wearing only trousers, T-shi and sox, is SAM LOOMIS, a good-looking, sensual shirt man with warm humorous eyes and a compelling smile. He is blo his neck and face with a thin towel, and is staring down Mary, a small sweet smile playing about his mouth. Mary k her face turned away from him. After a moment, Sam drops the towel, sits on the bed, lea over and takes Mary into his arms, kisses her long and wa holds her with a firm possessiveness. The kiss is disturb and finally interrupted by the buzzing closeness of an  inconsiderate fly. Sam smiles, pulls away enough to allow Mary to relax again against the pillow. He studies her, f at her unresponsiveness, then speaks in a low, intimate,  playful voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never did eat your lunch, did you. Mary looks at his smile, has to respond, pulls him to her kisses him. Then, and without breaking the kiss, she swin her legs over the side of the bed, toe-searches around, f her shoes, slips her feet into searches them. And finally pulls away and sits up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I better get back to the office.   These extended lunch hours give my  boss excess acid. She rises, goes to the bureau, takes a pair of small earr out of her bag, begins putting them on, not bothering or  perhaps not wanting to look at herself in the mirror. Sam watches her, concerned but unable to inhibit his cheery,  humorous good mood. Throughout remainder of this scene, t occupy themselves with dressing, hair-combing, etc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Call your boss and tell him you're  taking the rest of the afternoon  off. It's Friday anyway... and hot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (soft sarcasm)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do I do with my free afternoon,  walk you to the airport?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (meaningfully)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We could laze around here a while  longer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Checking out time is three P.M. Hotels  of this sort aren't interested in  you when you come in, but when your  time's up... (a small anguish)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam, I hate having to be with you in  a place like this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've heard of married couples who  deliberately spend occasional nights  in cheap hotels. They say it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupting)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When you're married you can do a lot  of things deliberately.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sure talk like a girl who's been  married.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, Mary. (after a moment)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My old Dad used to say 'when you  can't change a situation, laugh at  it.' Nothing ridicules a thing like  laughing at it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've lost my girlish laughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (observing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The only girlish thing you have lost.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a meaningful quiet,  then, with difficulty:)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam. This is the last time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This! Meeting you in secret so we  can be... secretive! You come down  here on business trips and we steal  lunch hours and... I wish you wouldn't  even come.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. What do we do instead, write  each other lurid love letters?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (about to argue, then  turning away)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I haven't time to argue. I'm a working  girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I'm a working man! We're a regular  working-class tragedy! (he laughs)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is tragic! Or it will be... if we  go on meeting in shabby hotels  whenever you can find a tax-deductible  excuse for flying down deductible  here...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupting,  seriously)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't laugh at it, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. It's like laughing through a  broken jaw, but... He breaks off, his cheeriness dissolved, goes to the wind tries to raise the shade. It sticks. He pulls at it. It comes down entirely, and the hot sun glares into the r revealing it in all its shabbiness and sordidness as if  corroborating Mary's words and attitude. Sam kicks at the fallen shade, laughs in frustration, grabs on to his humo again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And besides, when you say I make tax- deductible excuses you make me out a  criminal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (having to smile)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You couldn't be a criminal if you  committed a major crime.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wish I were. Not an active criminal  but... a nice guy with the conscience  of a criminal. (goes close to mary,  touches her)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Next best thing to no conscience at  all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pulling away)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have to go, Sam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can come down next week.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not even just to see you, to have  lunch... in public?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can see each other, we can even  have dinner... but respectably, in  my house with my mother's picture on  the mantel and my sister helping me  broil a big steak for three!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And after the steak... do we send  Sister to the movies and turn Mama's  picture to the wall?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam! No!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a pause, simply)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right. She stares at him, surprised at his willingness to contin the affair on her terms, as girls are so often surprised  when they discover men will continue to want them even af the sexual bait has been pulled in. Sam smiles reassuring places his hands gently on her arms, speaks with gentle a simple sincerity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary, whenever it's possible, tax- deductible or not, I want to see  deductible you. And under any  conditions. (a smile)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Even respectability.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You make respectability sound...   disrespectful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (brightly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm all for it! It requires patience  and temperance and a lot of sweating- out... otherwise, though, it's only  hard work. (a pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But if I can see you, touch you even  as simply as this... I won't mind. He moves away and again the weight of his pain and proble crushes away his good humor. There is a quiet moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm fed up with sweating for people  who aren't there. I sweat to pay off  my father's debts... and he's in his  grave... I sweat to pay my ex-wife  alimony, and she's living on the  other side of the world somewhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a smile)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I pay, too. They also pay who meet  in hotel rooms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A couple of years and the debts will  be paid off. And if she ever re- marries, the alimony stops... and  then...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I haven't even been married once  yet!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, but when you do... you'll swing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling, then with a  terrible urgency)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam, let's go get married.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And live with me in a storeroom behind  a hardware store in Fairvale. We'll  have a lot of laughs. When I send my  ex-wife her money, you can lick the  stamps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a deep desperation)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll lick the stamps. He looks at her, long, pulls her close, kisses her lightl looks out the window and stares at the wide sky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what I'd like? A clear,  empty sky... and a plane, and us in  it... and somewhere a private island  for sale, where we can run around  without our... shoes on.  And the  wherewithal to buy what I'd like. (he moves away,  suddenly serious)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary, you want to cut this off, go  out and find yourself someone  available.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm thinking of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a cheerful shout)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How can you even think a thing like  that!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (picking up handbag,  starting for door)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't miss your plane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, we can leave together can't we?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (at door)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm late... and you have to put your  shoes on. Mary goes out quickly, closing door behind her. As Sam st down at his shoeless feet,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shooting down at hotel entrance. Mary comes out, walks qu to a parked cab, gets in. The cab zooms up the awful stre

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small, moderately successful office off the main street cab pulls up at the curb. We see Mary get out of cab, pay driver, cross pavement to the office door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary enters office, crosses to her desk, sits down, rubs temples, finally looks over at Caroline, a girl in the la of her teens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isn't Mr. Lowery back from lunch?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a high, bright, eager- to-talk voice laced  to-with a vague Texan  accent)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's lunching with the man who's  buying the Harris Street property,  you know, that oil lease man...  so  that's why he's late. (a pause, then, as  Mary does not respond  to the pointed thrust)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You getting a headache?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It'll pass. Headaches are like  resolutions... you forget them soon  as they stop hurting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got aspirins? I have something...  not aspirins, but (cheerfully takes  bottle of pills out  of desk drawer)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: my mother's doctor gave these to me  the day of my wedding. (laughs)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Teddy was furious when he found out  I'd taken tranquilizers! She rises, starts for Mary's desk, pills in hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Were there any calls?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Teddy called.  Me... And my mother  called to see if Teddy called. Oh,  and your sister called to say she's  going to Tucson to do some buying  and she'll be gone the whole weekend  and... She breaks off, distracted by the SOUND of the door openi MR. LOWERY and his oil-lease client, TOM CASSIDY enter th office. Lowery is a pleasant, worried-faced man, big and trifle pompous. Cassidy is very faced loud and has a lunc hour load on. He is a gross man, exuding a kind of pitifu vulgarity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wow! Hot as fresh milk! You girls  should get your boss to air-condition  you up. He can afford it today. Lowery flashes an embarrassed smile at Mary, tries to lea Cassidy toward the private office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary, will you get those copies of  the deed ready for Mr. Cassidy. Cassidy pauses beside Mary's desk, hooks a haunch onto th desktop, smiles a wet smile at Mary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tomorrow's the day! My sweet little  girl... (laughs as Mary looks  up at him)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not you, my daughter!  A baby, and  tomorrow she stands up there and  gets her sweet self married away  from me! (pulling out wallet)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want you to look at my baby.   Eighteen years old... and she's never  had an unhappy day in any one of  those years! (flashes photo)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary glances, cannot bring herself to smile or make some  remark, continues sorting out the deed copies, tries to i the man's hot-breath closeness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, Tom, my office is air- conditioned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (ignoring Lowery)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what I do with unhappiness?  I buy it off! You unhappy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not inordinately. (puts deed copy into  Cassidy's too-close  hand)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm buying this house for my baby's  wedding present. Forty thousand  dollars, cash! Now that ain't buying  happiness, that's buying off  unhappiness! That penniless punk  she's marryin'... (laughs)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Probably a good kid... it's just  that I hate him. (looks at deed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yup! Forty thousand, says here... (to Lowery)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Casharoonie! He takes out of his inside pocket, two separate bundles o new $100 bills and throws them onto the desk, under Mary' nose. Caroline's eyes go wide at the sight of the gloriou green bundles of bills, and she comes close to the desk.  Cassidy leans terribly close to Mary, flicks through the  bills, laughs wickedly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never carry more than I can afford  to lose! (closer to Mary)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Count 'em!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shocked, worried)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom... cash transactions of this  size! Most irregular...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what? It's my private money! (laughs, winks, elbows  Lowery)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And now it's yours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (staring at the money)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I declare!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispering)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't! That's how I'm able to keep  it! (laughs)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hastily interrupting)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suppose we just put this in the safe  and then Monday morning when you're  feeling good...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Speakin' of feeling good, where's  that bottle you said you had in your  desk... (laughs, as if having  given away Lowery's  secret)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oops! (to Mary, patting her  arm)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Usually I can keep my mouth shut! He rises, reels toward Lowery's office, pauses, turns, sp to Mary, meaningfully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honest. I can keep any private  transaction a secret... any pri.... (stopped by Mary's  cold gaze)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lowery! I'm dyin' of thirstaroonie! Lowery starts after him, pauses, turns to Mary. Cassidy h gone into Lower's office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't even want it in the office  over the weekend. Put it in the safe  deposit box, at the bank, Mary. And  we'll get him to give us a check on  Monday - instead. He starts quickly away when it looks like Cassidy is goin to come and pull him bodily into the office. When the men are gone and the door is closed, Caroline picks up a bund smiles at it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was flirting with you. I guess he  noticed my wedding ring. Mary has put one bundle into a large envelope and takes t other from Caroline. When the bills are away, she puts th filled envelope in her handbag, notices the remaining dee copies on her desk, picks them up, goes to the private of door, knocks, starts to open door as:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary opens door, looks in. Cassidy is drinking from a lar tumbler, winks at her without pausing in his drinking. Ma remains on threshold a moment, then crosses to the desk,  talking as she goes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The copies. Mr. Lowery, if you don't  mind, I'd like to go right on home  after the bank. I have a slight...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You go right home!  Me and your boss  are going out to get ourselves a  little drinkin' done! (to Lowery)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Mary)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course. You feeling ill?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A headache.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You need a week-end in Las Vegas...  playground of the world!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to spend this week-end in  bed. (starts out)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Lowery)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only playground that beats Las Vegas! Mary goes back out into the outer office, closes door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary goes to her desk, takes the handbag, checks to make  sure the money-filled envelope is tucked well down into i During this:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aren't you going to take the pills? (as Mary shakes her  head)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They'll knock that headache out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't need pills... just sleep. She goes to the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A double bed in the foreground. We just see the far side the CAMERA SHOOTS across. Mary enters the scene, clad onl in her slip. Perhaps she is about to get into bed. Behind her is an open closet, but too dark inside for us to see contents. As Mary turns to the closet the CAMERA LOWERS t show a close view of the $40,000 in the envelope on our s of the bed. Mary takes a dress from the closet and starts to put it o as the CAMERA RETREATS to reveal a packed but not yet clo suitcase also on the bed. Mary zips up her dress and then brings some final garments from the closet. She comes around to the suitcase and puts them on the top Mary works with haste and in tension, as if acting on an  impulse which might vanish as quickly as it came. The suitcase filled now, she checks around the room, then takes her handbag to the bed, puts in the money-filled  envelope, and then slams the suitcase shut. Then filled s looks at her small bedroom desk, goes to it, removes a sm file-envelope from one of the drawers. It is one of those brown envelopes in which one keeps important papers and  policies and certificates. She checks its contents briefl puts it on the bed, opens another desk drawer, takes out bank book, tosses it on the bed. Then she packs both the  file-envelope and the bank book, into her handbag, takes quick last look around the room, picks up the handbag and the suitcase and goes out of the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A two-car garage. One car is gone. Mary's car is parked i the driveway. The CAMERA is low enough so that we can eas read the Arizona number plate in the foreground. Mary comes out of house, starts for the trunk, intending put the suitcase in, changes her mind, places the suitcas and her handbag on the front seat, gets in, starts the ca begins to back out of driveway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are close on Mary's car, shooting in at her troubled,  guilty face. She seems to be driving with that excess car of one who does not wish to be stopped for a minor traffi irregularity. She stops for a red light at a main  intersection.

dialogues.speaker: FROM MARY'S VIEWPOINT
dialogues.text: We see Lowery and Cassidy crossing the street, passing ri in front of Mary's car.

dialogues.speaker: MARY'S CAR
dialogues.text: Mary freezes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cassidy, glancing into car, sees Mary, lets out a cheery  exclamation, elbows Lowery. Lowery turns, sees Mary, smil pleasantly, pulls Cassidy on.

dialogues.speaker: MARY'S CAR
dialogues.text: Mary watches the entire exchange with a look of stony hor on her face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now we look closely at Lowery. As he reaches the curb, a  small confusion brightens his face. He remembers that Mar intended to "spend the weekend in bed." He considers,  curiously, turns, looks back at her, a slight frown on hi face.

dialogues.speaker: MARY'S CAR
dialogues.text: Mary sees the pause and the look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For a moment it even looks as if Lowery might be meaning cross back to the car.

dialogues.speaker: MARY'S CAR
dialogues.text: Mary's tension is unbearable. And at that moment we hear shrill shriek of the traffic cop's whistle. Mary zooms the car away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary in car, driving, safely away from town. Her look is  less tense now, and more purposeful. After a moment, she  checks the fuel gauge, frowns, looks along highway for a station.

dialogues.speaker: MARY'S CAR
dialogues.text: Approaching and leaving city limits.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Looks at gas gauge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see Mary's car drive in, come to a stop. There are no  other cars about, this being a gas station off the main  highway, and the attendant is obviously in the shack. Mar looks worried about having to make this stop, keeps her f turned away from the shack, not wishing it to be seen. No one comes and for a moment Mary considers driving on, if the emptiness of the station were a warning, an omen t she should listen to. But the gas registers almost empty. She has to blow her horn. A YOUNG MAN comes out of the shack, starts toward her car At that moment, we HEAR the RINGING of the TELEPHONE in t shack. The Attendant walks a few steps further, toward Ma car, then decides to go back and answer the phone. The ph insistent ringing unnerves Mary. She starts her car, zooms off. We see the Attendant, phone in hand, in the doorway of sh He looks after the departing car with little or no expres

dialogues.speaker: CAR
dialogues.text: The car grows smaller as it races up the road. The sun is setting. There is something vaguely ominous about the  darkening sky into which the car seems to be disappearing

dialogues.speaker: MARY IN CAR
dialogues.text: The oncoming headlights hurt Mary's eyes. She is getting  sleepy and her vision is blurring. Her eyes close,  involuntarily, snap open again. She stretches than wide, if forcing them to stay open. The oncoming lights seem to glare to a point beyond endurance. She murmurs "Sam - Sam

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see Mary's car, dim in the early dawn, tilted on the s shoulder of the road, looking somehow sad and pathetic, l a child's thrown-away toy. And from this angle it would a that the car is empty. After a moment, during which there are no other vehicles  passing, we see, coming from the far distance, a HIGHWAY  PATROLMAN in a patrol car. He passes Mary's car, notes it apparent emptiness, U-turns, comes back up behind the car He gets out and approaches the driver's side window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Patrolman looks down into the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary turns with a start, sits up, is startled and unnerve by the sight of the Patrolman, and, as if by automatic re turns the ignition and presses down on the starter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Patrolman holds up his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (startled)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold it there! Mary slams down on the brake, tries to pull herself toget The Patrolman raps again, less gently. Reluctantly, Mary rolls down the window. The Patrolman st her for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In quite a hurry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. (because he seems to  be awaiting an  explanation)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't mean to sleep so long. I  was afraid I'd have an accident last  night, from sleepiness... so I decided  to pull over...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You slept here all night?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a faint edge of  defensiveness)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. As I said, I couldn't keep my  eyes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mere concern)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are plenty of motels in this  area. You should have... I mean,  just to be safe...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't intend to sleep all night! I just pulled over... have I broken  any laws?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, m'am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then I'm free to go...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is anything wrong?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course not! Am I acting as if...  something's wrong?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (almost a smile)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frankly, yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please... I'd like to go...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is there what? (not waiting for an  answer)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've told you there's nothing wrong...  except that I'm in a hurry and you're  taking up my time...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupting, sternly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now wait just a moment! Turn your  motor off, please. Mary seems about to object, thinks better of it, turns of the ignition.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the course of my duty, I never  "take up" anyone's time, whether  it's to give a warning, or a ticket,  or help! Believe that, M'am. (a little softer)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now if you woke up on the wrong side  of... the car seat, that's one thing.  But when you act as if I've just  placed you under arrest...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No need to apologize... Mary starts the car, her face turned as if she wishes the matter were all settled and the Patrolman had already gon The Patrolman isn't exactly one of those civil servants w demands a thank-you, but he does feel her manner is a bit too abrupt. He calls:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait a minute!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (jamming down the  brake)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now what? The Patrolman gazes at her a moment, then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May I see your license?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please. Mary pulls her handbag up from the floor, where she'd pla it when she stretched out for sleep. She puts her hand in it, rummages for her wallet, cannot find it. The Patrolman is staring at her. She glances at him nervo pokes in her bag a bit more, sighs, realizes she'll have remove some of its contents. Nervously, badly controlling her fear, she takes out the money-filled envelope, and th the important papers envelope, filled then a couple of ot items, places them on the seat, finally finds her wallet, opens it, hands it to him. He looks at the wallet, then a the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Patrolman walks around to the front of the car, check the license plate, and returns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Patrolman peers in, checks the car registration on th steering wheel, returns Mary's wallet. She takes it, looks at him for a flicker of a moment. He says nothing. She starts ahead, fast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Patrolman stares after Mary as she drives off, then s back to his automobile.

dialogues.speaker: MARY IN CAR
dialogues.text: She is quite shaken, realizes she caused herself a great  deal of trouble and placed herself in unnecessary danger. She is disturbed and angry and frightened at her inabilit to act normally under the pressure of guilt. As she drive she glances into her rear-view mirror.

dialogues.speaker: MARY'S REAR-VIEW MIRROR
dialogues.text: The Patrolman is following in his automobile, keeping beh her at a matched speed.

dialogues.speaker: MARY IN CAR
dialogues.text: She glances out at her surroundings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Freeway ahead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She suddenly turns off the highway.

dialogues.speaker: MARY IN CAR
dialogues.text: She checks her mirror.

dialogues.speaker: MARY'S REAR-VIEW MIRROR
dialogues.text: The Patrolman is no longer following, has not turned off  after her.

dialogues.speaker: MARY IN CAR
dialogues.text: She breathes a sigh of relief, thinks a moment, makes a q decision.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The big sign reads "California Charlie - Automobile Parad We see Mary's car drive onto the lot and stop. Mary gets of the car, glances toward the lot office, turns her atte to the line of cars, notice the California licence plates all of them. The CAR DEALER calls out from his office:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With you in a second! Mary nods, starts walking along the line of cars as if ma a selection. Her eye is caught by the iron newspaper stan on the corner, just outside the lot. She stares at the papers, turns away, as if what she is  fearing would have to be impossible, then, having to sati herself, goes to the stand, drops a dime in the iron slot picks up a LOS ANGELES newspaper, starts back into the ca lot as she glances worried at the front page. As she goes we see, coming up the street toward the lot, the same  PATROLMAN. He sees Mary, slows, swerves over to the oppos side of the street, stops by the curb. Mary, engrossed in the newspaper, and walking back ease the lot, does not se the Patrolman. The car dealer is out on the lot now, standing and waitin for Mary. As she approaches, lost in her newspaper, he sm

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm in no mood for trouble!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (glancing up, thrown  for a moment)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cheerfully)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's an old saying, "First customer  of the day is always the most  trouble!" But like I said, I'm in no  mood for it so I'm just going to  treat you so fair and square you  won't have one human reason to give  me...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupting)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I trade in my car and take  another?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can do anything you've a mind  to... and bein' a woman, you will! (chin-indicating her  car)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That yours?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, it's... nothing wrong with it,  I'm just...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sick of the sight of it! (laughs)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, suppose you look around for  something that strikes your eyes and  meanwhile I'll have my mechanic give  yours the once over and... want some  coffee? I was just about...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Thank you. I'm in... a hurry. I  just want to make a change and  start... She stops suddenly, almost with a gasp. She has seen the  Patrolman.

dialogues.speaker: THE PATROLMAN
dialogues.text: He is staring over at her, his face dispassionate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary has to force herself to look away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One thing people never ought to be  when they're buying a used car is in  a hurry! (starting away toward  her car)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But like I said, too nice a day for  arguing. I'll just shoot this into  the garage. He starts into Mary's car. She looks at him, in near pani wanting to skip the whole thing. Torn, wondering if the  presence of the Patrolman doesn't negate the value of cha cars, wondering how she can get away, wondering if she'll followed, or if the Patrolman will go away if she does st here. All these panic-fears rush her mind and she can do nothin The Car Dealer has driven her car into the garage. She st in the middle of the lot, feeling like a shooting target. She looks toward the garage.

dialogues.speaker: THE GARAGE
dialogues.text: Mary's car is in it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary decides she cannot back out now without arousing fur suspicion, is compelled to look again at the Patrolman.

dialogues.speaker: THE PATROLMAN
dialogues.text: He still watches. With a self-angry sigh of resignment, s goes to a close car, looks at it. The Car Dealer is retur

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the one I'd've picked for you  myself!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How much?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go ahead! Spin it around the block.  Now I know you don't know anything  about engine condition, but you can  feel, can't you... and it's all in  the feel, believe me, you feel that  one around the block...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It looks fine. How much will it be,  with my car...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean you don't want the usual  day and a half to think it over? (laughs)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are in a hurry! Somebody chasin'  you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course not. Please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... heck, this is the first time  I ever saw the customer high-pressure  the salesman! (laughs, sees she is  in no mood for it)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd figure roughly... (looks at the car,  then back at the  garage)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...your car plus five hundred.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Five hundred.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aha! Always got time to argue money,  huh...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right. As the car dealer looks at her in amazement, she reaches  into her bag, feels the money-filled envelope, pauses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (slowly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I take it... you can prove that car's  yours... I mean, out of state and  all... got your pink slip and your...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I have the necessary papers.  Is there a Ladies Room...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the building ... (indicates, continues  to stare quietly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary starts for the building, glancing  once in the direction of the  Patrolman.

dialogues.speaker: THE PATROLMAN
dialogues.text: He still sits, his motor throbbing, his face quiet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary goes into the office building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary enters, locks door, takes envelope out of her handba extracts one bundle of bills from the envelope, counts of five, puts the bundle back into the envelope and the enve back into the bag. Then she remembers, takes out the impo papers envelope, goes through it, finds several papers ha to do with her car, takes them all out, puts back the  envelope, starts out of the ladies Room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Car Dealer has moved the car of her choice out of the line. It stands in the clearing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (too cheerfully)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you'd better give it a trial  spin. Don't want any bad word of  mouth about California Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd really rather not. Please.  Can't  we just settle this and...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be perfectly honest with you,  Ma'am. It's not that I don't trust  you, but...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupting)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But what?  Is there anything so  terribly wrong about... making a  decision and wanting to hurry? Do  you think I've stolen... my car?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, M'am. I was only about to say,  I've sent my mechanic out to give  your car a little test... that's  all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (handing him the  ownership papers and  the new bills)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd like to be ready when he gets  back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. If you'll come along... He starts toward the office building. Mary follows, close anxiously. She glances, sees:

dialogues.speaker: THE PATROLMAN
dialogues.text: He is still at the far curb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Car Dealer goes into his office. Mary follows.

dialogues.speaker: THE PATROLMAN
dialogues.text: A second later, he starts his automobile, checks traffic, comes across the street, slowly, and drives onto the lot. pauses a moment, then drives across the lot, passing the  office, going on to the other exit, stops there as Mary's car is driven back onto the lot. The MECHANIC stops Mary's car, hops out, waves to the  Patrolman. The Patrolman waves back, goes on a bit until is behind Mary's car, stops again, looks over at the offi In a moment, Mary comes out, hurries across to her new ca gets in, starts the motor. The Mechanic yells:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey! Miss? Mary pauses, turns, sees the Patrolman, then the Mechanic Her face goes white. She doesn't know which man called he Then the Mechanic waves, starts forward with her suitcase

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as Mechanic reaches  car)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just put it right in here, please...  beside me. The Mechanic smiles, throws the suitcase in. Mary zooms o As she drives out of lot we see the Mechanic, the Car Dea and the Patrolman all looking after her.

dialogues.speaker: MARY IN NEW CAR ON ROUTE
dialogues.text: Mary is driving tensely. She checks the rear-view mirror, more shocked than pleased when she sees...

dialogues.speaker: MARY'S REAR-VIEW MIRROR
dialogues.text: No sign of the Patrolman.

dialogues.speaker: MARY IN NEW CAR ON ROUTE
dialogues.text: She turns her face, looks out at the highway.

dialogues.speaker: ROUTE 99
dialogues.text: It is heavy with traffic.

dialogues.speaker: MARY IN NEW CAR ON ROUTE
dialogues.text: Again she checks the mirror and although...

dialogues.speaker: MARY'S REAR-VIEW MIRROR
dialogues.text: There is still no sign of the Patrolman.

dialogues.speaker: MARY IN NEW CAR ON ROUTE
dialogues.text: She cannot relax or feel safe, cannot convince herself th nothing will come of the man's watching and suspicions. CAMERA IS CLOSE on Mary's face now, recording her anxiety her fears. Her guilt shines bright in her eyes and she is person unaccustomed to containing this much guilt in this realistic a situation. Suddenly, we hear the SOUND of the Used Car Dealer's laugh, hear it as clearly as Mary hears in her imagination. The "imagined voice" we hear is actua the voice of the Car Dealer:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Heck, Officer, that was the first  time I ever saw the Customer high- pressure the Salesman!  Somebody  chasing her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I better have a look at those papers,  Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She look like a wrong-one to you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Acted like one. Mary blinks, shakes her head, as if trying to shake away  these voices of her imagination. She checks the rear-view mirror.

dialogues.speaker: MARY'S REAR-VIEW MIRROR
dialogues.text: Still no sight of the Patrolman.

dialogues.speaker: MARY IN NEW CAR
dialogues.text: She tries to force herself to relax, almost succeeds when she is sprung to tension again by....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sight of a police car. As she drives past, we hear th squeaky, unintelligible voice coming over the car radio.  Mary zooms down on the gas, whizzes ahead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary's car dashing along.

dialogues.speaker: MARY IN NEW CAR
dialogues.text: Mary looks weary, tired with strain and with hard driving Her eyes are heavy with worry and deep thought.

dialogues.speaker: OUT THE WINDSHIELD
dialogues.text: We can see that it is much later in the day, almost dusk.

dialogues.speaker: MARY IN NEW CAR
dialogues.text: We HEAR the sound of an agitated BUZZ of an intercom syst a sound emanating from Mary's imagination. After the second BUZZ, we HEAR the voice of Caroline.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Mr. Lowery.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a worried tone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Caroline...? Mary still isn't in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Mr. Lowery... but then she's  always a bit late on Monday mornings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Buzz me the minute she comes in. Again Mary shakes her head, forces herself to stop hearin these "invented" scenes of her imagination.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now we cut to the view of the road, from Mary's viewpoint Darkness of evening is coming. In the dim twilight we see the neon sign of roadside restaurants and gas stations  beginning to blaze on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back on Mary's face, and after a moment, the imagined voi again:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Call her sister! If no one's answering  at the house....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I called her sister, Mr. Lowery,  where she works, the Music Makers  Music Store, you know? And she doesn't  know where Mary is any more than we  do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You better run out to the house.   She may be... unable to answer the  phone...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her sister's going to do that.  She's  as worried as we are. A flush of painful guilt and regret rises up in Mary's fa She closes her eyes for one tight swift moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We cut again to the highway. The first oncoming headlight slash at the windshield.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cutting back to Mary, we can sense by the tense muscles o her face that she is driving faster. The oncoming headlig blurt at her. Suddenly we HEAR Lowery's voice, loud now and frightened, if the anxiety in the man's voice was strong enough to br through Mary's effort to keep her mind silent and her  imagination blank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! I haven't the faintest idea.  As  I said, I last saw your sister when  she left this office on Friday...  she said she didn't feel well and  wanted to leave early and I said she  could. And that was the last I saw... (a pause, a thought)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...wait a minute, I did see her, an  hour or so later, driving... (a pause, then with  solemn fear)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, I think you'd better come over  here to my office. Quick. (a pause, a click)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Caroline, get Mr. Cassidy for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is completely dark now, night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We cut back to her face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After all, Cassidy, I told you...   all that cash... I'm not taking the  responsibility... Oh, for heaven's  sake, a girl works for you for ten  years, you trust her! All right,  yes, you better come over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fast cut back to Mary's face. Oncoming headlights throw a blinding light across her features.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (undrunk, sharp with  rage)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well I ain't about to kiss off forty  thousand dollars! I'll get it back  and if any of it's missin' I'll  replace it with her fine soft flesh!  I'll track her, never you doubt it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold on, Cassidy... I still can't  believe... it must be some kind of a  mystery... I can't...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You checked with the bank, no?  They  never laid eyes on her, no?  You  still trustin'? Hot creepers, she  sat there while I dumped it out...  hardly even looked at it, plannin'  and... and even flirtin' with me...! A look of revulsion makes Mary close her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: THROUGH THE WINDSHIELD AGAIN
dialogues.text: Big drops of rain begin to appear.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: She is becoming aware of the rain starting.

dialogues.speaker: THROUGH THE WINDSHIELD
dialogues.text: The rain increasing and backlit by the oncoming headlight

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Mary starts the windshield wipers.

dialogues.speaker: THROUGH THE WINDSHIELD
dialogues.text: The wipers are having a battle with the now torrential ra

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Peering through the blurred windshield.

dialogues.speaker: THE CAR WHEELS
dialogues.text: slowing down in the flooding highway.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: peering through the windshield. The oncoming lights are f

dialogues.speaker: THE CAR WHEELS
dialogues.text: almost coming to a slow turn.

dialogues.speaker: THROUGH THE WINDSHIELD
dialogues.text: just blackness and rain.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: peering.

dialogues.speaker: MARY'S VIEWPOINT
dialogues.text: An almost undiscernible light in the far distance, a neon sign blurred by the rain-sheeted windshield.

dialogues.speaker: MARY'S CAR
dialogues.text: She presses down, forces the car to move on through the  flooded road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As we move closer, we see the neon sign more clearly and faintly make out the large letters which read "Motel."  M stops the car, lowers the window slightly, looks out. We the sign clearly now: "BATES MOTEL." Mary opens the car d and dashes out into the rain and up onto the porch of the motel office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary pauses on the porch. The lights are on within the of She tries door, finds it open, goes into office. CAMERA  FOLLOWS her into office. There is no one present. Mary go to the desk, rings a small pushbell. There is no response Mary rubs her forehead in weariness and frustration, goes back out onto the porch. She looks off in another directi slightly behind the office, and sees...

dialogues.speaker: MARY'S VIEWPOINT
dialogues.text: A path from the motel office leads directly up to this ho There is a light on in one of the upstairs rooms. A WOMAN passes the window, pauses, peers out. We see her in clear silhouette. She quickly goes away fro the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary, having seen the woman, expects now that she will ge some attention. She stands a few moments, waiting. No one comes. Impatience and anger rise in Mary. She dash out into the rain, to her car, gets in, opens the side wi begins to honk the horn. After a moment, a YOUNG MAN open the front door of the house, pauses, starts down the path After a few steps, he turns and runs back into the house. Mary leaves her car, starts a dash for the shelter of the porch. As she runs, we see that the Young Man has gone ba only to get an umbrella. Seeing that Mary is on her way t the porch, he runs quickly, the umbrella unopened in his  hand. He gets to the porch a moment after Mary has reache it. He stops short, looks at her, then at the umbrella hangin useless in his hand, then back to her. There is something sadly touching in his manner, in his l Mary's impatience goes and she smiles and this makes him  almost smile. He gestures her into the office, standing b to indicate that he will go after her. She goes into the  office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Young Man follows Mary in, closes the door. He is NOR BATES, somewhere in his late twenties, thin and tall, sof spoken and hesitant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dirty night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (not really a question)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have a vacancy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (simply, almost  cheerfully)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have twelve vacancies. Twelve  cabins, twelve vacancies. (a pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They moved away the highway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought I'd gotten off the main...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I knew you must have. No one stops  here anymore unless they do. He is behind the counter now, pushing forward the registr book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But it's no good dwelling on our  losses, is it.  We go right ahead  lighting signs and following the  formalities...  Would you sign,  please. Mary has placed her handbag on the counter. She takes the registration book, picks up the pen, is suddenly struck w the realization that she'd better use an alias. She write the name Marie Samuels.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your home address. Oh, just the town  will do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (glancing at newspaper  sticking out of her  handbag)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Los Angeles. She realizes he didn't ask her to tell him, merely to wri it down. She smiles, writes Los Angeles beside the false  name. Norman smiles, stops smiling out of embarrassment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cabin One. It's closer in case you  want anything... right next to the  office.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: He removes a key for Cabin One. We see that there is a  remaining key on the board.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want sleep more than anything.   Except maybe, food.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a big diner about ten miles  on up... just outside Fairvale.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Am I that close to Fairvale?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fifteen miles. I'll get your bags. He goes to door, opens it. The rain has slowed down  considerably. He smiles at this fact, as if to communicat some pleasure he finds in it. Mary follows him to the doo goes out on the porch, waits and watches as Norman runs t her car, gets in, drives it to the parking space in front Cabin One. Mary walks along the porch, waits before the d of Cabin One. Norman gets out of car, with suitcase, runs to the door,  opens it, pushes the door open, puts his hand in and swit on a light. Mary goes into the cabin. Norman follows her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norman places suitcase on bed, goes to the window, opens

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stuffy in here. (turns to her)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... the mattress is soft and  there're hangers in the closet and...  stationary with "Bates' Motel" printed  on it in case you want to make your  friends back home envious... and...  the... over there.... (he points to the  bathroom, fairly  blushes)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quickly, starting to  leave)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be in the office if you want  anything... just tap on the wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Mr. Bates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norman Bates. He pauses at the door, gazes at her. She smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have something most girls never  have.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's no name for it... But it's  something that, that puts a person  at ease.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. Again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (not really a question)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not going to go out again and  drive up to that diner, are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then will you do me a favor? (without waiting for  her response)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you have supper here?  I was  just about to, myself... nothing  more than some sandwiches and a lot  of milk, but I'd like it if you'd  come up to the house and... I don't  set a fancy table but... the kitchen's  awful homey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd like to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, you get your dresses  hanging out and... change those wet  shoes, and I'll come for you soon as  it's ready... (starts out)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...with my trusty umbrella. (he laughs a small  laugh, runs off)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary closes the door, goes to suitcase, opens it, starts take out a dress. Her handbag is next to the suitcase. Sh glances down into it, pauses, drops the dress, reaches in the handbag, takes out the money-filled envelope, stares it, almost with regret, filled contemplates hiding it, de to, starts looking for a reasonable hiding place. She loo about, at the closet, the drawers etc., realizes all such places are obvious. Catching sight of the newspaper in he bag, she hits on a solution. She opens the newspaper, pla the envelope within it, lock-folds the paper again and th places it on the bedside table as if it were there for la reading. She considers this for a moment, accepts it, goe to her suitcase to start unpacking. Suddenly the quiet is shattered by the shrill, ugly sound a woman's voice, raised in anger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! I tell you no! Mary walks slowly to the window, realizing that the terri voice is coming from the house behind the cabins. CAMERA  FOLLOWS her to window and once there we see the light is  still on in the upstairs bedroom and the voice is coming  from that room. The rain has stopped and the moon is out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I won't have you bringing strange  young girls in for supper... (an ugly, sneering  note creeps into the  voice)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...by candlelight, I suppose, in the  cheap erotic fashion of young men  with cheap, erotic minds!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mother, please...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And then what? After supper, music?  Whispers?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mother, she's just a stranger...   hungry, and the weather's bad...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mimicking cruelly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mother, she's just a stranger! (hard, cruel again)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As if men don't desire strangers, as  if... oh, I refuse to speak of  disgusting things because they disgust  me! You understand, Boy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go on, go tell her she'll not be  appeasing her ugly appetite with my  food... or my son! Or do I have to  tell her, cause you don't have the  guts? Huh, boy? You have the guts,  boy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (blurted cut fury and  shame)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut up! Shut up! There is the SOUND of a door closing in that room up ther Mary has stood by the window, listening with mounting dis and concern and sympathy. She turns her face away now, ga sadly at the little empty room. In a moment there is the SOUND of the house's front door  slamming shut. Mary turns, looks out the window.

dialogues.speaker: FROM MARY'S VIEWPOINT
dialogues.text: We see Norman coming down the path, carrying a napkin-cov tray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary looks at him for a moment, then turns quickly, goes the door, opens it and goes out onto the porch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary pauses outside the door, is about to start forward w Norman comes round the building and walks along the porch past the office, stopping only when he is close to her. H stares with painful embarrassment at the knowing look in eye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've caused you some trouble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mother... (a hollow little laugh,  an attempt at sardonic  humor)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...what is the phrase... "she isn't  herself today"... I think that's it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking at the tray)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You shouldn't have bothered. I really  don't have that much of an appetite. Norman flinches, realizing she has heard his mother's  reference to Mary's appetite.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. I wish... people could  apologize for other people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry about it. (a warm smile)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But as long as you've made us supper,  we may as well eat it. Huh? She begins to back into her room. Norman starts to follow hesitates as he sees the total picture of an attractive y woman and a motel room. Bringing down the tray of food, i defiance of his mother's orders, is about the limit of hi defiance for one day. He cannot go into Mary's room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It might be nicer... warmer in the  office. Without waiting for approval or disapproval, he turns, hu to the office. Mary looks after him, her face showing amu sympathy, then follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norman looks about, tray in hand, sees there is no reason place to spread out a supper. He turns, sees Mary standin in the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eating in an office... (a rueful smile)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...to officious, even for me. I have  the parlor behind this... if you'd  like. Mary nods. Norman walks on, behind the counter and into t darkened parlor. Mary follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the darkened room, lit only by the light from the offi spilling in, we see Norman placing the tray on a table. M comes to the doorway, pauses. Norman straightens up, goes lamp, turns on the light. Mary is startled by the room. Even in the dimness of one  lamp, the strange, extraordinary nature of the room rushe up at one. It is a room of birds. Stuffed birds, all over the room, on every available surface, one even clinging t the old fashioned fringed shade of the lamp. The birds ar of many varieties, beautiful, grand, horrible, preying. M stares in awe and a certain fascinated horror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please sit down. On the sofa. As Norman goes about spreading out the bread and ham and  pouring the milk, we follow Mary across the room. She stu the birds as she walks, briefly examines a bookcase stack with books on the subject of "Taxidermy."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She notices, too, the paintings on the wall; nudes, prima and many with a vaguely religious overtone. Finally Mary reaches the sofa, sits down, looks at the sp

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're very... kind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's all for you. I'm not hungry.   Please go ahead. Mary begins to eat, her attitude a bit tense. She takes u small slice of ham, bites off a tiny bite, nibbles at it the manner of one disturbed and preoccupied. Norman gazes at her, at the tiny bite she has taken, smil and then laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You eat like a bird.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'd know, of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not really. I hear that expression,  that one eats "like a bird," is really  a falsie, I mean a falsity, because  birds eat a tremendous lot. (A pause, then  explaining)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I don't know anything about birds.  My hobby is stuffing things...  taxidermy. And I guess I'd just rather  stuff birds because...  well, I hate  the look of beasts when they're  stuffed, foxes and chimps and all...  some people even stuff dogs and  cats... but I can't... I think only  birds look well stuffed because  they're rather...  passive, to begin  with... most of them... He trails off, his exuberance failing in the rushing retu of his natural hesitancy and discomfort. Mary looks at hi with some compression, smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a strange hobby. Curious, I  mean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uncommon, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I imagine so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not as expensive as you'd think.  Cheap, really. Needles, thread,  sawdust .. the chemicals are all  that cost anything. (He goes quiet, looks  disturbed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A man should have a hobby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's more than a hobby... sometimes...  a hobby is supposed to pass the time,  not fill it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a pause, softly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is your time so empty?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, no! (forcing brightness  again)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I run the office, tend the cabins  and grounds, do little chores for  mother... the ones she allows I might  be capable of doing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You go out... with friends?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Friends? Who needs friends. (Laughs, then with  gallows humor)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A boy's best friend is his mother. (Stops laughing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've never had an empty moment in  your whole life. Have you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only my share.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are you going? I don't mean to  pry...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (A wistful smile)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm looking for a private island.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you running away from?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Alert)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do you ask that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. People never run away from  anything. (A pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The rain didn't last very long. (Turning suddenly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what I think? I think we're  all in our private traps, clamped in  them, and none of us can ever climb  out. We scratch and claw... but only  at the air, only at each other, and  for all of it, we never budge an  inch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sometimes we deliberately step into  those traps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was born in mine. I don't mind it  anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should... mind it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh I do... but I say I don't. (Laughs boyishly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Staring at him,  shaking her head  softly.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If anyone ever spoke to me, the way  I heard... The way she spoke to you,  I don't think I could ever laugh  again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Controlled resentment)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sometimes when she talks that way to  me I'd like to... curse her out and  leave her forever! (A rueful smile)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or at least, defy her. (A pause, a hopeless  shrug)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I couldn't. She's ill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She sounded strong...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean... ill. (A pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She had to raise me all by herself  after my dad died... I was only  five... and it must have been a  strain. Oh, she didn't have to go  out to work or anything, Dad left us  with a little something... anyway, a  few years ago... Mother met a man.  He talked her into building this  motel... We could have talked her  into anything... and when.  Well...  It was just too much for her when he  died, too... And the way he died...  Oh, it's nothing to talk about when  you're eating. (Pauses, smiles)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anyway, it was too much of a loss  for my mother... she had nothing  left.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Critically)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Except you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A son is a poor substitute for a  lover. (Turns away as if in  distaste of the word)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you go away?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To a private island, like you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, not like me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's too late for me. And besides...  who'd look after her? She'd be alone  up there, the fire would go out...  damp and cold, like a grave. When  you love someone, you don't do that  to them, even if you hate them. Oh,  I don't hate her.  I hate... what  she's become. I hate... the illness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Slowly, carefully)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wouldn't it be better if you put her  in... someplace... She hesitates. Norman turns, slowly, looking at her with striking coldness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An Institution? A madhouse?  People  always call a madhouse "someplace." (Mimicing coldly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Put her in Someplace!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry... I didn't mean it to  sound uncaring...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (The coldness turning  to tight fury)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean about caring?  Have  you ever seen one of those places?  Inside? Laughing and tears and cruel  eyes studying you... and my mother  there?  Why? has she harmed you?   She's as harmless as... one of these  stuffed birds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am sorry. I only felt... it seemed  she was harming you. I meant...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (High fury now)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well? You meant well?  People always  mean well, they cluck their thick  tongues and shake their heads and  suggest so very delicately that... The fury suddenly dies, abruptly and completely, and he s back into his chair. There is a brief silence. Mary watches the troubled man, is almost physically paine by his anguish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Quietly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've suggested it myself. But I hate  to even think such a thing.  She  needs me... and it isn't... (Looks up with a  childlike pleading  in his eyes)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...it isn't as if she were a maniac,  a raving thing... it's just that...  sometimes she goes a little mad. We  all go a little mad sometimes. Haven't  you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (After a long  thoughtful pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, and just one time can be enough. (Rises)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Cheerfully, correcting)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Norman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not going to... to your room  already?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm very tired. And I'll have a long  drive tomorrow. All the way back to  Phoenix.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phoenix?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I stepped into a private trap back  there -- and I want to go back and...  try to pull myself out. (Looking close at  Norman)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Before it's too late for me, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Looking at her)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you stay a little while,  just for talking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd like to, but...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright. I'll see you in the morning.  I'll bring you breakfast.  What time  will you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very early. Dawn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright, Miss... (He has forgotten her  name)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's it. (He frowns, as if  bothered by not being  able to match the  name to the memory  of the name in the  registration book)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good night. She goes out of the parlor. We see her, from Norman's  viewpoint, as she crosses the small office, goes out into the night. Norman turns and looks at the table, and we se his face now. It is bright with that drunken-like look of determination and encouragement and like resolve. He star to clean up the table, pauses as he hears the closing of  Mary's door in the cabin next door. He holds still, listens. He goes into the office and look at the book.

dialogues.speaker: M.S.
dialogues.text: He goes back into the parlor with a mystified expression. The sound of Mary moving about her room come over, soft  SOUNDS, somehow intimate in the night quiet. Norman turns his ear from the direction of the SOUNDS, seems to be fig an impulse to listen, or more than listen. But slowly, he is forced to surrender to the impulse and, resisting himself, he goes to the wall, presses the side his head against it. The SOUNDS come louder, as if we too had our ear pressed against the wall. Now Norman looks at picture hanging on the far end of the wall he is leaning  against. Slowly he starts toward it. He reaches it, touches it, reluctantly lifts the small fr off the wall. A tiny circle of light hits Norman's face, coming from th hole in the wall behind the picture. This end of the room very dim and thus we are able to see clearly the light  striking Norman's face. We move close to Norman, extremely close, until his profi fills the screen. The tiny spot of light hits his eye. Se the small hole through which the light comes. Norman peep through.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN'S VIEWPOINT
dialogues.text: Through the hole we look into Mary's cabin, see Mary  undressing. She is in her bra and halfslip. She stoops ov a bit, places her hands behind her upper back, begins to  unhook her bra.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: He watches as Mary removes her bra. We see his eye run up and down the unseen figure of Mary.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN'S VIEWPOINT
dialogues.text: Mary, just slipping into a robe, covering her complete nu

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: He turns from the hole, faces us for a moment, continues  turning until he can look out the small parlor window. We see, as he sees...

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: He turns his face away, quickly, resentfully. In his face see anger and anguish. And then resolve. Quickly, precisely, he rehangs the picture over the hole the wall, turns, starts out of the parlor. We see him go  through the office and out onto the porch, not even bothe to close the door behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norman walking along the porch, in the direction of the b house. Once on the path he pauses, looks up at the light the bedroom window, then pulls himself up, squares his  shoulders, strides manfully up the path. CAMERA follows behind him. He opens the door of the house enters. We see him pause at the foot of the stairway, loo up at the bedroom door just at the head of the stair. He  holds for a moment, and then his resolve and courage  evaporates. His shoulders slump, sadly, mournfully. He by passes the stairs and slowly makes his way to the kitchen At the far end of the hall. He enters the kitchen, drops  wearily into a chair. After a moment, he stretches out a and gently pushes the kitchen door closed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary is seated at the small desk, engrossed in figuring i small notebook. We see from these figures a calculation w indicates her intention to make a restitution of the mone she has used of the forty thousand dollars. We see, too, bankbook. The paper reads thus: top figure, 40,000; direc beneath it 500, the amount used for the new car; total af subtraction, 39,500. In another spot we see a figure whic matches the balance in her bankbook; 624.00. Beneath this is the figure 500, and the amount after  subtraction, 124.00. She studies the figures, sighs, not  wearily but with a certain satisfaction, with the pleasur that comes when one knows that at any cost one is going t continue doing the right thing. After a moment she tears page out of the notebook and, rising, begins to rip it in small pieces. She goes into the bathroom, drops the piece into the toilet bowl, flushes the toilet. Then she drops robe and steps into the tub and turns the shower on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Over the bar on which hangs the shower curtain, we can se the bathroom door, not entirely closed. For a moment we w Mary as she washes and soaps herself. There is still a small worry in her eyes, but generally s looks somewhat relieved. Now we see the bathroom door being pushed slowly open. The noise of the shower drowns out any sound. The door is then slowly and carefully closed. And we see the shadow of a woman fall across the shower  curtain. Mary's back is turned to the curtain. The white  brightness of the bathroom is almost blinding. Suddenly we see the hand reach up, grasp the shower curta rip it aside.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: As she turns in response to the feel and SOUND of the sho curtain being torn aside. A look of pure horror erupts in her face. A low terrible groan begins to rise up out of h throat. A hand comes into the shot. The hand holds an eno bread knife. The flint of the blade shatters the screen t an almost total, silver blankness.

dialogues.speaker: THE SLASHING
dialogues.text: An impression of a knife slashing, as if tearing at the v screen, ripping the film. Over it the brief gulps of  screaming. And then silence. And then the dreadful thump Mary's body falls in the tub.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The blank whiteness, the blur of the shower water, the ha pulling the shower curtain back. We catch one flicker of glimpse of the murderer. A woman, her face contorted with madness, her head wild with hair, as if she were wearing fright-wig.  And then we see only the curtain, closed acr the tub, and hear the rush of the shower water. Above the shower-bar we see the bathroom door open again and after moment we HEAR the SOUND of the front door slamming.

dialogues.speaker: THE DEAD BODY
dialogues.text: Lying half in, half out of the tub, the head tumbled over touching the floor, the hair wet, one eye wide open as if popped, one arm lying limp and wet along the tile floor. Coming down the side of the tub, running thick and dark a the porcelain, we see many small threads of blood. CAMERA FOLLOWS away from the body, travels slowly across the  bathroom, past the toilet, out into the bedroom. As CAMER approaches the bed, we see the folded newspaper as Mary p it on the bedside table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: beside the bed. The CAMERA now moves away over to the win and looks up to the house, and as it gets there we HEAR,  coming from within the house, the SOUND of Norman's fearf shocked voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
