dialogues.text: Mother! Oh God, what... blood,  blood... mother...! We cannot entirely distinguish these exclamations. After a moment or two of silence, Norman emerges from the front door, dashes down the path toward the motel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norman is coming AT CAMERA, running head-on. He dashes in an extreme close up and we see the terror and fear ripe i his face. CAMERA PANS as Norman races past, holds as Norm runs to the porch and quickly along it and directly to Ma room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norman pauses a moment in the doorway, glances about the  room, hears the shower going, sees the bathroom door is o He goes to the bathroom, looks in, sees the body. Slowly, almost carefully, he raises his hands to his face covers his eyes, turns his face away. Then he crosses to window, looks out at the house. Shot is so angled that we see the bedside table with the newspaper on it. After a moment, Norman moves from the window, sinks onto edge of the bed.

dialogues.speaker: BEHIND NORMAN
dialogues.text: Norman sitting on bed, the bathroom in b.g. of shot. We c see only the hand of the dead girl, lying along the tile  floor. Norman presses his eyes, fights to find a way out his dilemma. Slowly, a kind of settling comes upon him, t peace that comes with decision. Norman rises, goes to the window, looks out, and then, wi resolution, closes the window and draws the curtain acros it. Then he crosses to the front window, facing the porch and draws those curtains closed. Then he switches off the bedroom light, leaving the room lit only by the spill fro the bathroom. He opens the front door, goes out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norman comes out of Mary's cabin, closes the door careful behind him, goes along the porch to his office, goes in. stay outside. Immediately, the "Vacancy" sign goes off, a then the motel sign goes off. As CAMERA GOES closer to th office, the lights within go off and we HEAR a closet doo opening and then the SOUND of a pail being picked up. Nor comes out of office, closes door, looks cautiously about, goes along porch, carrying pail with mop in it, goes into Mary's cabin, closing the door after him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With the paper in the foreground, Norman enters. We can s him in the dim spill of light. He pauses by the door, the gathers his strength and goes into the bathroom. We HEAR set the pail on the tiled floor, and then we HEAR the sho being turned off. And there is total silence. CAMERA MOVE FORWARD so that we can see into bathroom. CAMERA is ANGLED that we see Norman only from the waist u Quickly and deftly he unhooks the shower curtain, emerges with it into the bedroom. CAMERA PANS down and we see him spread the shower curtain on the bedroom floor, just outs the bathroom door. He spreads the curtain so that one end it comes up against the bathroom threshold and slightly o and onto the tile floor. Again he goes into the bathroom CAMERA TILTS up so that we see only the upper half of Nor He works carefully, with his arms extended away from his  body, slowly pulls the dead body out of the tub, drags it across the tile floor and onto the spread-out shower curt in the bedroom. Having arranged the body, he straightens examines his hands, sees bloodstains on them. He returns the bathroom, goes to the hand-basin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see his hands being washed, see the bloodstains being  diluted and washed away by the gush of the faucet water.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: We see Norman shake his hands free of the water, then tur to the job of cleaning the bathroom. He places the pail in the tub, runs water into it, dips t mop in, swabs the tile floor. With a towel he wipes off t wall over the tub and the edges and sides of the tub and  even the shower curtain rod. Then he takes a second towel and goes over the cleaned areas, carefully drying them.   Finally he rinses and squeezes out the mop, empties the p cleans out the tub, and goes out into the bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norman steps carefully around the unseen body, crosses to the desk, starts going through Mary's handbag, in search her car keys. He suddenly notices them lying on the desk, where he'd thrown them after parking her car. He picks up the keys, crosses the room, goes out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see Norman pauses at the door, check cautiously, then  hurry across the porch and into Mary's car. He circle-tur the car, so that its trunk is backed up to the turns porc directly opposite Mary's door, as close as it can go. Then he alights, goes to the trunk, opens it with the key and, leaving the trunk lid raised, goes back into the cab

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From a raised angle, we see Norman bend down and begin to wrap the shower curtain around the body. We see the edges the curtain as they are raised and laid down again. Then picks up the wrapped body, crosses to the door, uses his  foot to pull the door open, and, leaving the door open be him, goes quickly across the porch and gently lays the bo in the trunk. He closes the lid then, but does not lock i He comes back into the cabin, closes the door completely, flicks on the light. Again the newspaper is in the foreground. For a moment he pauses, closes his eyes against the realization of what h is doing, then quickly pushes all thoughts away, continue with his work. With the room lighted, he now proceeds to  gather up all Mary's articles and toss them into the suit He checks all drawers and the closet, gets down and check under bed and bureau, goes into the bathroom, checks that room again, comes back into the bedroom, looks about  carefully, spots Mary's handbag, throws even that into th suitcase, is finally satisfied that all traces of the gir are gone from the room. Then he closes Mary's suitcase, p it up. With his free hand he picks up the pail, in which are the mop and the used towels. He crosses to the door, switches off the light with his shoulder, pulls open the door, sta out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Norman stands in the doorway, he is suddenly and blind lit by the bright headlights of a passing car. The flash the lights and the SOUND of the SPEEDING CAR are over in flicker of a moment, but it takes a few seconds for Norma to regain his former tense composure. Then he goes to the car trunk, raises it with his foot, throws the suitcase a the pail into it, slams it shut. He pauses a moment, then realizes he has left the bathroom light on in Mary's cabi He returns to cabin. As he enters, his eye is caught by t newspaper on the bedside table. He goes to it, takes the  newspaper, and looks once again into the bathroom. His gl goes right over the toilet bowl. He turns out the lights, crosses the darkened cabin, goes out onto the porch. He reopens the trunk, tosses in the newspaper and closes He goes around and jumps into the car and starts away. We HOLD on the trunk, follow it for a while, then

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The car pulls away from a CLOSE ANGLE on the trunk and as CAMERA HOLDS we see that we are now in a swamp area. It is quiet except for the irritating noises of night ins Norman stops the car at the very edge of the swamp, turns off the lights, gets out, leaving door open. He looks at swamp, seems doubtful of its ability to swallow up the ca realizes he has no choice. He leans into the car, release the emergency brake, starts to push. The front of the car begins to roll into the swamp. Suddenly there is the LOW, THROBBING SOUND of a motor. Norman freezes, listens. The SOUND grows louder and Norman realizes it is an airpl flying overhead. The car is rolling quickly now. Norman j away, slams the door shut, stands tense. The SOUND of the plane overhead grows louder. Norman looks up.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN'S VIEWPOINT
dialogues.text: We see no plane. The SOUND of the motor is beginning to  diminish.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: We see the relief in his face. He looks at the car. More than two-thirds of it have already sunk into the swa The trunk alone seems to hold poised above the sand and s as if refusing to go the rest of the way. Norman begins t panic, he steps dangerously close, pushes with his foot. slowly the car sinks, until finally it is gone and we hea only the gentle plop of the swamp's final gulp, and see o the small after-bubble, like a visual burp. Norman waits a moment, then begins stamping out the tire  marks, so obvious in the wet ground around the swamp. He stamps and drags his feet over the markings as we:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: standing on the porch of the motel, leaning against a pos He is staring out into the night, a look of guarded, casu innocence on his face, as if he were taking one last mome of peaceful night air before retiring. Then he glances do and CAMERA follows his gaze. A hose is lying on the groun outside Mary's cabin, its stream of water obliterating th tire marks. After a moment, Norman's hand comes into shot, picks up h places it in a new position. As CAMERA PULLS BACK, we see that the water from the hose has erased and rearranged th road markings so that it would be impossible to tell that car had been parked here. After a short wait, Norman goes to the hose-faucet, turns off, unscrews the hose. As he rolls the hose, he walks aw from the spot, past the office, heading for the path that leads to the house. He goes up the path, pauses at the st of the house, tosses the curled hose onto the lawn, goes the steps and into the house. CAMERA FOLLOWS him in, PAUS as he pauses at the foot of the stairs. Norman goes up th stairs. On the landing he stops. The door to his mother's room is closed. Lying in a heap outside the door are a blood-stai dress and a pair of elderly-woman's shoes. From an EXTREM HIGH ANGLE, we look down on Norman as he bends to pick up the stained dress and shoes. He rolls the shoes into the dress, tucks the small, neat  bundle under his arm, and starts down the stairs, heading for the basement.

dialogues.speaker: THE OLD HOUSE
dialogues.text: It stands silhouetted against the sky. There is a long wa Then, slowly, a curl of smoke comes out of the chimney.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam is seated at his desk, writing a letter. Sequence begins with CAMERA IN CLOSE, over Sam's shoulder, and we read as mush as he has written of the letter. The letterh reads "Sam Loomis - Hardware," and the letter reads: "Dea right-as-always Mary: I'm sitting in this tiny back room  which isn't big enough for both of us, and suddenly it lo big enough for both of us. So what if we're poor and cram and miserable, at least we'll be happy! If you haven't co to your senses, and still want to... CAMERA begins PULLING AWAY as Sam turns the sheet of pape over, continues backing away out of the small back room a heads, backwards, down the corridor, we see a young clerk BOB SUMMERFIELD, Sam's assistant, standing behind the cou a look of handsome patience on his face. He is waiting on meticulous, elderly woman customer, who is holding and  examining a large can of insecticide. As CAMERA PASSES:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...They tell you what its ingredients  are and how it's guaranteed to  exterminate any insect in the world,  but they do not tell you whether or  not it's painless. And I say insect  or man, death should always be  painless. CAMERA, by this has reached the front door of the hardwar store and we now see a girl standing just inside the door She is an attractive girl with a rather definite manner, look of purposefulness. She carries a handbag and a small overnight case. She is Mary's sister, LILA CRANE. Bob Summerfield has noticed Lila, smiles brightly at her, gives her an I'll-be-with-you-in-a-moment nod. Lila starts to walk toward the counter, never taking her  eyes off Bob. As she approaches, she asks quietly:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want to see Sam?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam Loomis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (yelling toward back  room)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam! Lady wants to see you! Lila looks to the back room. The woman customer goes on  worriedly examining the fine print of the insecticide can Sam comes to the door of his room, pauses, looks at Lila moment, starts toward her, his expression indicating that does not know her. Lila studies him with a quiet, worried expression.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May I talk to you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a bit mystified)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure... Lila glances at the customer and the clerk, turns, starts toward the front of the store. Sam holds a moment, then  follows. As he reaches her, she turns, her eyes studying intently as she says:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Mary's sister.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lila.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quickly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is Mary here? Sam is mystified, and is also aware of the worried, hosti expression on Lila's face. He studies her for a quiet mom Behind them is a display of various size carving knives.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is something wrong?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to know if my sister is here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know where. In your store,  somewhere in your town... anywhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you know? As Sam is about to speak, the Woman Customer comes sailin past, speaking as she goes and wearing a satisfied smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All I can do is hope if it isn't  painless, it's quick! She speaks "quick" with a kind of delicious bite, nods  happily, goes on out of the store. Sam is now staring  apprehensively at Lila.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What should I know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To begin with, where Mary is. Do  you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I take it you don't either? (As Lila shakes her  head)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Last Friday. She left work, and  home... I was in Tucson over the  weekend... I haven't heard from her,  not even a phone call.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you thought she'd come up here,  to me? If she had, what reason would  she have for not calling you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A good reason, I suppose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Slightly exasperated)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well what do you think, we eloped or  something? Or we're living in sin  and...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Loomis, you're so busy being  defensive that you haven't even  reacted to the most serious fact of  all. Mary is missing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was getting to that!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you know about it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing! You're putting me on the  defensive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, if you two are in this thing  together, I don't care, it's none of  my business... But I want to see  Mary. I want her to tell me she's  all right and it's none of my  business. Then I'll go back to Phoenix  and... She stops, the anxiety and fear building up in her, her e beginning to fill with worried tears. Sam studies her for moment, then turns and calls:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob? Run out and get yourself some  lunch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's okay, Sam, I brought it with  me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Run out and eat it. Bob gets the message, goes out through the back way. Sam goes closer to Lila, speaks with soft seriousness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What thing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What thing could we be in together?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (A pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hate tears. (Takes out hankie)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is Mary... in trouble?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well why didn't she come to me...   call me...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not that kind... (Almost a smile)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You men and your egos.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Seriously)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never mind my ego. Let's talk about  Mary. Their attention is distracted by a man who has strolled  quietly into the room. He ignores them, walks past them,  goes behind the counter, takes down a sign reading "CLOSE FOR LUNCH," walks back to the door, closes door, hangs th sign across the door window, locks the door, turns to Sam and Lila, folds his arms, smiles a particularly unfriendl smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's all talk about Mary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who are you, friend?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milt Arbogast, Private Investigator. (To Lila)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where is she, Miss Crane?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wouldn't have been able to tail you  if you did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's your interest?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Money. There is a moment's silence and then, unable to tolerate sudden frightening happenings, Sam explodes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somebody better tell me what's going  on and tell me fast! I can take so  much and then...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Interrupting calmly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your girl friend stole forty thousand  dollars. Sam looks at Arbogast in utter shock and in that state as one of those seemingly ridiculous questions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (An almost amused  smile)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Must've needed it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you talking about? (To Lila)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She was supposed to bank it, on  Friday, for her boss. She didn't. And no one has seen her since.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Looking at Sam)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Someone has seen her. Someone always  sees a girl with forty thousand  dollars. (To Sam)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is your girl friend, isn't she?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam, they don't want to prosecute,  they just want the money back. It  was all in cash...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Correcting with  Cassidy's word)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Casharoonie!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam, if she's here...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She isn't! A real look of anguish comes into Lila's face. And Arboga studies it, then speaks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You came up here on a hunch, Miss  Crane? Nothing more? No phone call...  from him, or from your sister herself?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (wearily)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not even a hunch. Just hope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With a little checking, I could get  to believe you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (anxiously)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't care if you do or... I want  to see Mary... before she gets in  any deeper...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you check in Phoenix...  hospitals... maybe she had an  accident... a hold-up...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She was seen leaving town in her  car. Seen by her very victims, I  might add.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a moment)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't believe it. (to Lila, slowly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a thoughtful pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes... I just... did. The moment  they told me...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You might have doubted for say five  minutes or so, Sister. Lila turns from Sam, a flush of guilt and regret in her f Arbogast looks at her, quiet sympathetically.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're always quickest to doubt people  who have a record for being honest.   I think she's here, Miss Crane. Where  there's a boyfriend... (Trails off, smiles  encouragingly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She won't be back there among the  nuts and bolts... but she'll be in  this town... somewhere. I'll find  her. He nods, takes down the closed-for-lunch sign, sails it t the counter, opens door, goes out into the street. After a quiet moment:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just listened... and believed  everything they told me. 'She stole  the money.' 'We don't want to get  her in trouble.' 'No don't bring the  police in'...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was her boss' idea not to report  it to the police?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. The man whose money she... he  talked so loud and fast, and I... I  should've called the police.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He must have had a darn good reason  for wanting them kept out of it...   All that cash...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I ought to call the police right  now!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not? Sam, is she hiding here?   Are you two planning to go away with  the money?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How could I go away? I'm in debt up  to my... (Smiles at the  incongruity of his  reply, then goes  serious)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If she did steal that money...  It's  hard to believe she did because it's  hard to see why she would. Unless  she had some wild idea that it would  help me... us...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She haven't even called you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't see her... and I didn't  hear from her! Believe that!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need to... I need to believe  something. This is the first time  I've ever come up against anything I  couldn't... understand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've led a charmed life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I just think... anything can be  explained. But Mary, doing a thing  like this... I don't know how to  handle...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe we can handle it together. (He smiles  encouragingly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (A rueful shrug)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I came flying up here expecting to  get some explanation... for all I  know, she may be trying to get in  touch with me, at home. I'd better  go home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (A thoughtful pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think she'll contact me if she  contacts anybody. Why don't you stay  here. When she shows up... or calls...  be here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (A long study, her  suspicion of him  evaporating)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want me to stay here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She'll need both of us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (considers, then:)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where... can I stay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (brightly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First rate hotel, fifty yards up the  street. Come on. (as he reaches for  the closed-for-lunch  sign)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After we check you in we'll go to  the drugstore and get you a sandwich.  Then we'll come back here... and  wait. He hangs the sign on the door, ushers Lila out, closes do behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They emerge from the store and walk along to the hotel. they enter, Arbogast is in the act of taking over a white Ford sedan from a rental car man. They glance at him and returns a cynical look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Outside another hotel we see Arbogast alight from the whi car and go into new hotel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The white car speeding along the highway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arbogast going into the office - we see the sign above hi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A high shot showing the freeway and Bates house and motel the side old highway. A pause and then across the bottom the picture a white car speeds by on the freeway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another Hotel. Arbogast goes in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The white car speeding along the freeway again going in t opposite direction to last time. Norman, a tiny figure, i seen going up the steps to his mother's house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arbogast's search is getting down in the scale. This is a entrance to a cheesy boarding house. "Rooms to Rent," etc He looks at his list and then goes in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The white car goes by on the freeway again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arbogast goes in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Heavy traffic on the freeway. A beat or two - again the w car. It slows up opposite the distant motel. It makes a t and goes back out of scene. A pause and it reappears on t old road and slowly makes its way toward the Bates' Motel

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We now see Norman. He has brought out an old rocking chai and has placed it on the office porch and is sitting hunc in it. And he is darning one of his own socks. CAMERA HOL Beyond the porch, and Norman, we see the old house and ca barely make out, in the twilight dimness, the figure of h mother seated at the window. Here, too, there is that qua of quiet peace surrounded by a vague foreboding. Now Norman looks up at the SOUND of the approaching car. And continues looking as the car comes to a stop and Arbo gets out. Arbogast gives the place a quick once-over, gaz at Norman, starts forward. In his steps and manner there that bored, routine-logged quality of a man who has seen many motels and asked question of too many hotel managers over too short a period of time. Norman rises as Arbogast comes forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shoving sock in his  pocket)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I always forget to put the sign on,  but we do have vacancy. (Cheerfully)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twelve in fact. Twelve cabins, twelve  vacancies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pleasantly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the past two days I've been to so  many motels, my eyes are bleary with  neon. This is the first one that  looked like it was hiding from the  world at large.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't really forget the sign, it  just doesn't seem... any use. (Points)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This used to be the main highway. (Starts for office)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Want to register, please?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sit down. I don't want to trouble  you, just want to ask...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No trouble. Today's linen day. I  change all the beds once a week,  whether they've been used or not...  dampness. I hate the smell of  dampness. (Opening office door)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's such a dank smell. Norman is holding the door open, so Arbogast walks in. Norman follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norman switches on the overhead light, starts for the lin closet, suddenly pauses, turns, studies Arbogast, who has remained standing by the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You out to buy a motel?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. I thought... you said you'd been  to so many in two days...  What was  it you wanted to ask?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm looking for a missing person. (takes out and opens  wallet and extends  it as he speaks)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My name's Arbogast, private  investigator... (takes back wallet  when Norman doesn't  look at it)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trying to trace a young girl who's  been missing almost a week. From  Phoenix. (A look at Norman's  frightened expression)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a private matter... family wants  to forgive her... (smiles)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She isn't in trouble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (forcing a smile)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't think the police went  searching for people who weren't in  trouble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not the police.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. He waits a moment, then opens closet, starts counting out sheets and pillow cases, keeps his back to Arbogast. Arbogast takes a photograph out of his pocket, talks as h crosses to Norman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have reason to believe she came  this way... might have stopped in  this area... (extends photograph,  which Norman doesn't  glance at)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did she stop here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. No one has stopped here in  weeks...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mind looking at the picture before  committing yourself?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Committing myself to what? You sure  talk like a Policeman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at the picture. Please. Norman glances, briefly, turns away, lifts sheets and pil cases off the shelf holds them close, almost protectively

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. At least I don't recall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She might have used an alias. Mary  Crane's the real name, but she  might've registered...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupting)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't even bother with guests  registering any more... I mean, little  by little, you drop the formalities. (more relaxed, because  Arbogast is listening  with a pleasant smile)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I shouldn't even bother to change  the linen. I guess habits die hard.  Which reminds me... He goes to the wall, flips a light switch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The vacancy sign. Just in case. We had a couple the other night, said if the sign hasn't  been on they'd have thought this was an old deserted mini town or something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now there's a couple even remarking  about your sign, and see how easily  you forgot them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You thought no one has stopped here  in weeks. Now, try to remember if  this girl...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (A pause, a study)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe she even signed the register...  because habits die hard. Let's check  it, huh? Norman says nothing. Arbogast goes to the desk, pulls the registry book around, flips back a page or two. Norman simply stares at the man. Arbogast hums faintly,  pleasantly, as he examines the pages. Then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes sir! Marie Samuels.  Interesting  alias. He takes a slip of paper out of his pocket, lays it besid the signature in the registry book, all the while nodding and smiling nicely, as if this discovery will make Norman happy as it is making him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't know where she got "Marie,"  but "Samuels" figures. Her boy  friend's name is Sam. (Turns to Norman, the  smile gone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was she in disguise? Or do you want  to check the picture again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't lie to you. I just have  trouble keeping track of... time. Arbogast has reached him, the picture extended. Norman lo dutifully at it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was raining and her hair didn't  look like that... damped out, I guess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me all about her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She arrived kind of late, wet and  hungry and she was very tired and  went right to bed and left early.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How early?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very early. Dawn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of which morning?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The following morning. Sunday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No one met her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or arrived with her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She didn't call anyone? Even locally?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You didn't spend the whole night  with her did you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! Of all...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you know she didn't make a  call?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She was tired. She said she had a  long drive ahead of her, in the  morning... Yes, now I'm remembering  very clearly because I'm picturing.  When you make a picture of the moment  in your mind, you can remember every  detail. She was sitting back there,  no she was standing up, with some  sandwich still in her hand, and she  said she had to drive a long way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back where?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You said she was sitting "back there,"  or standing rather...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. My private parlor. She had an  awful hunger... so I made her some  supper. And then she went to bed and  left in the morning. I didn't even  see her leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How did she pay you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cash or check? For the cabin...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cash.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And when she left, she never came  back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why should she? I'm sorry, I have  work to do, Mr... if you don't mind...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do mind. If it don't jell, it ain't  aspic! (smiles)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This ain't jelling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know what you expect me to  know about... people come and go...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She isn't still here, is she?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not at all!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suppose I wanted to search the cabins,  all twelve... would I need a warrant?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as if pleasantly  exasperated)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, if you won't believe me, go  ahead. You can help me make beds if  you like. (laughs, shakes his  head)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on. He starts out. Arbogast pauses, momentarily confused by t young man's openness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norman walks down the porch, hesitates before Cabin One,  walks on a bit toward Cabin Two, stops, turns to see if  Arbogast is following. Arbogast has come out onto the por but is not following. He has walked to the opposite end o the porch and is standing at its edge, looking up at the house. The upstairs window is in darkness. The neon of th Vacancy and Motel signs splash strange light over the sce

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Change your mind? Arbogast does not reply. Norman becomes apprehensive, sta to Arbogast, forcing himself to remain calm and cheerful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess I've got one of those faces  you can't help believing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Norman, but  continuing to stare  at the house)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anyone at home?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I live there. Alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Someone is sitting in that window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My mother. Arbogast turns, gazes seriously at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's... ill. Confined to her room.  It's practically living alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If this girl Mary Crane were here,  you'd have no reason to hide her  would you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If she paid you well?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, look...!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or if she had you say... gallantly  protecting her... you wouldn't be  fooled... you'd know she was just  using you. Wouldn't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not a fool! And I'm not capable  of being fooled! Not even by women!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't mean that as a slur on your  manhood. I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (disturbed now)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's all right. maybe she could  have fooled me.  But... (a rueful smile)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She didn't fool my mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your mother met her? (quickly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I talk to your mother?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I told you, she's confined...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just for a moment. She might have  picked up a hint you'd miss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sick old women are sharp. Come on, I  won't disturb...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! Just no!  I have one of those  breaking points like any other man,  believe it or not, and I'm near it. There's just so much pushing I can  take and I think...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right! (starts away, toward  his car, pauses)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Might save me a lot of leg-work if I  could just talk to your mother.  But  I'd need a warrant for that, won't

dialogues.speaker: I
dialogues.text: Norman does not respond. Arbogast gets in his car, starts the motor. Norman looks up, studies the man's face, his o face showing apprehension. Arbogast backs the car around  very slowly, his gaze divided between the old house and t lighted window of Cabin Two. As he turns the car out, his headlights light up the porch. Norman stands, watching him drive away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The car pulls up and Arbogast gets out of car, leaving mo running. As he starts to walk across the highway, CAMERA  PULLS AWAY and we

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arbogast gets to the phone booth, enters. CAMERA STARTS  FORWARD, and we see Arbogast remove a small notebook from his pocket, check on a number, drop a dime in the slot an dial this number. As we reach phone booth,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Crane, please. (listens)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She leave a number? (listens)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks. (hangs up, dials again,  waits)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lila there, Mr. Loomis? Arbogast. (waits)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lila? Look, this isn't much, but it  might make you feel a little better.  Mary was up here. Spent last Saturday  night at Bates'  Motel, out here on  the old highway. (listens)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Young fellow runs it, said Mary spent  the night, left, period! (listens)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I did question him, believe me. I  think I got all there was to get.   Just have to try to pick up the scent  from here. (listens)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... maybe that's because I don't  feel entirely satisfied.  He's got a  sick old mother, confined type, and  I think she saw Mary and talked to  her. Shame, too... confined old women  love to talk to strangers. (listens)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was, but I think I'll go back to  the motel, first. (listens)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, you stay put, Lila. With Loomis.  I should be back in an hour. (listens)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right. And Lila... You'll be  happy to know what I think. I think  our friend Sam Loomis didn't even  know Mary was here. (smiles)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See you in an hour. Or less. He hangs up, gets out of the phone booth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A distant view of the House and Motel. There is a light o in the house. There is also a light on in Norman's office We see Norman emerge from his office and move along the p toward the distant cabins. He carries sheets on his arm. goes into the last cabin and switches the light on. Into foreground the hood of the white Ford enters the scene an stops. Arbogast gets out. He goes over to the Motel offic

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arbogast goes in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arbogast looks around the empty office and calls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bates! He goes over to the door to the parlor and enters. He loo around the bird-ridden room. He stops short as he sees:

dialogues.speaker: C.U.
dialogues.text: goes over to it. He finds it unlocked. With a quick, caut look around he opens it.

dialogues.speaker: C.U.
dialogues.text: straightens up and goes out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arbogast comes out and looks off. He sees:

dialogues.speaker: THE LAST LIT CABIN
dialogues.text: The door ajar.

dialogues.speaker: C.U.
dialogues.text: would go along but he stops with a new thought. He turns  around and looks off.

dialogues.speaker: C.U.
dialogues.text: comes to a decision. He goes off.

dialogues.speaker: L.S. ARBOGAST
dialogues.text: dashes up the stone steps to the House.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA HOLDS as Arbogast goes up onto the porch. The hous is dark within except, as we can now see, for a faint spi of light in the foyer, light which comes from the upstair hall. Arbogast goes to the living room window, looks in,  sees only darkness. Then he goes to the door, listens for along moment, hears nothing. Very slowly, almost painfully, he turns the knob of the d and pushes gently with his arm and shoulder. The door beg to open. He allows it to open just enough for him to slip through and into the foyer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arbogast gradually eases the door closed, stands against waiting. He looks up in the direction of the light, sees one. The door at the head of the stairs is closed. Arboga listens, holds his breath, hears what could be human soun coming from upstairs but realizes these could also be the sounds of an old house after sunset. After a careful wait he crosses to the stairs, starts up, slowly, guardedly,  placing a foot squarely on each step to test it for squea or groans before placing his full weight on it. CAMERA  FOLLOWS, remaining on floor level but TRAVELLING ALONG th stairway as Arbogast makes his way up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see Arbogast coming up the stairs. And now we see, too the door of the mother's room, opening, carefully and slo As Arbogast reaches the landing, the door opens and the m steps out, her hand raises high, the blade of an enormous knife flashing.

dialogues.speaker: C.U.
dialogues.text: The knife slashes across his cheek and neck. Blood spurts The sudden attack throws him off balance. He stumbles bac and staggers down the whole of the staircase. He frantica gropes for the balustrade as he goes backwards down the  stairs. The CAMERA FOLLOWS him all the way. A wicked knif keeps thrusting itself into the foreground. As he collaps at the bottom, the black head and shoulders of Mrs. Bates plunges into the foreground as the CAMERA MOVES IN to con the raising and descending murder weapon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lila is sitting close by the phone, and looks as if she h moved from it in the last hour. Sam is pacing, occasional stopping at the window, glancing out, pacing again. The a tray close to Lila is filled. There is a thick atmosphere of smoke, tension and wearine in the small, otherwise cozy room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (at window, quietly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sometimes Saturday night has a lonely  sound. Ever notice, Lila?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (unable to keep up  small talk)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam. He said an hour. Or less.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's been three.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are we just going to go on sitting  here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (suddenly cheerful)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He'll be back. Let's sit still and  hang on, okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have an awfully nice habit, Sam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hundreds! Which one is your pet?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whenever I start contemplating the  panic button, your back straightens up and your eyes get that God-looks- out-for-everybody look and... I feel  better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I feel better when you feel better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a pause - then she  rises)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's the old highway?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want to run out there, bust in  on Arbogast and the sick old lady,  shake her up and maybe spoil  everything Arbogast's been building  for the last three hours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That wouldn't be a wise thing to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patience doesn't run in our family. Sam, I'm going out there!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arbogast said...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An hour! Or less! Sam stares at her, frowns in concern over her very real  anxiety, goes to the phone, dials operator.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got the number of the motel out on  the old highway? Bates, I think. (waits)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam! Why call when we can go?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And maybe pass Arbogast on the road? (into phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks. He presses down the receiver, releases it, dials Bates' Motel. The faint other-end ringing tones can be heard,  repeatedly, annoyingly. He waits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Lila)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Probably on his way back right now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam, I'm going.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hangs up and picks  up his jacket)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll never find it. He starts for the door. Lila follows after him into the s

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pauses halfway down, turns, puts his hands on her arms

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stay here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why can't I go out there with you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looks at her)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know... (he collects himself)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One of us has to be here in case  Arbogast's on the way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nervously)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just wait here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a warm smile)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Contemplate your... panic button. He hurries down to the street door and out. CAMERA HOLDS Lila as she stares after Sam. As she stands alone in the  darkened store, all the hardware seems to take on siniste shapes. C.U. Among some bathroom fittings a nozzle from a shower falls onto the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lila turns and picks if from the floor and puts it back i its place. She turns and again looks to the deserted stre with a touch of anxiety. She gives a slight unconscious  shiver.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tall and lonely still against the moonlight, the figure o Norman, silhouetted. He doesn't move, merely stands there the edge of the swamp, staring down at the now calm and q face of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All light are out, except the light in Norman's mother's  room. And her figure can be seen sitting in the window,  relaxed in a high-back chair, her face turned into the ro After a second, we hear the SOUND OF A MOTOR, and then Sa small pick-up truck swings into the driveway. Sam stops the motor, automatically switches off headlight pauses as he observes the silence and darkness of the are Then he hops out of the cab, goes quickly to the office,  knocks on the door. As he waits for a response, he looks  down the long porch, studies the darkened cabins, knocks  again, louder, looks in the other direction and sees the  house and the figure at the one lit window. He stares a m then calls loudly:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arbogast?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The silhouette of Norman. He is still. Over shot, very di comes the SOUND OF SAM'S VOICE, calling again for Arbogas Norman turns slowly until, in silhouette, we see his prof his chin lowered furtively as he looks over his shoulder the direction of the house. There is silence for a moment and then again the SOUND of Sam POUNDING at the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The store is in darkness, only the glow from the back roo spilling in. L.S. With CAMERA placed with its back to the street door, we c see the distant tiny figure of Lila seated and waiting in the back room beyond. There is a SOUND of a car pulling u The tiny figure jumps up and runs all the way from the ba room down the aisle of hardware and comes into a BIG HEAD We see Lila's desperate anxious look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From her viewpoint we see Sam alighting from his truck an coming toward the door of the store. He enters. He and Li exchange quiet glances.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He didn't come back here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (worriedly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No Arbogast. No Bates. And only the  old lady at home... (frowning)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A sick old lady unable to answer the  door... or unwilling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where could he have gone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe he got some definite lead. Maybe he went right on...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Without calling me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a hurry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam, he called me when he had nothing  definite, nothing but a dissatisfied  feeling. Don't you think he'd have  called if he had anything...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupting)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. I think he would have. Lila goes quiet. Sam starts toward the back room, pauses the doorway, turns. Lila has remained by the door, lookin out at the street. She feels his pause, turns, and for a  moment they share at each other across the darkened room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's go see Al Chambers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's the Deputy Sheriff around here. As he starts forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A dark, quiet, tree-ceilinged street, the small neat hous dim in the moonlight. Sam's pick-up truck comes down the  street, pulls up before the house of Sheriff Chambers. CA MOVES IN on Sam and Lila as they remain for a moment in t truck's cab, staring quietly at the sleeping house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our Deputy sleeps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing.  Just... all the lights  out... must be asleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a small exasperation)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does that mean we can't...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I'm just procrastinating.  People  hate when the doorbell rings in the  middle of the night. (gives up, starts out)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on. He gets out of cab, goes around to help Lila. She is alre out. CAMERA FOLLOWS them up the small path to the front d Sam presses the bell button. Both he and Lila are almost  knocked over by the shocking, clanging, ear-splitting BLA OF THE BELL within the house, a ring which sounds more li a fire alarm than a doorbell. He tries to smile, fails. Lila doesn't even try. The  downstairs hall light goes on and a moment later the door unhesitatingly opened by MRS. CHAMBERS, a small, lively s of a woman wrapped in a thick flannel robe and a corona o hospitality.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, Mrs. Chambers. I hate bothering  you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You didn't! (a cross look up at  the bell)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's tinkerbell. (a quick smile at  Lila)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Al wants to be sure he'll hear it if  anyone rings it in the middle of the  night. (to Sam)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well come on in, at least! As she opens the door wide,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fat roses splatter the wallpaper. The stairs are carpeted The lighting is bright. There is a perfectly fitting wall phone by the parlor arc Mrs. Chambers goes to the stairway, yells up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Albert! (a tiny wait, a smile  as Sam and Lila enter)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Al Chambers! Sam is about to close the door behind him. Mrs. Chambers  motions for him not to, scurries across the hall, leans  outside, presses the doorbell. The RING within the house even more shattering. She closes the door, starts to the  stairway, pauses as the SOUNDS of movement above COME OVE SHOT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Customers! SHERIFF CHAMBERS comes down the stairs, in a bathrobe whi matches his wife's. He is a tall, narrow man with a face  originally destined for Mount Rushmore. He nods at Sam, l at him with wide-awake eyes and a no-nonsense concern.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have a problem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Lila)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's go out back and have some coca  while the men are talking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, thank you. It's my problem, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know where to start... (a look at Lila)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Except at the beginning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Sheriff)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is Lila Crane, from Phoenix. She's been here for a few days,  looking for her sister. There's a  private detective helping... and,  well, we got a call tonight, from  this detective, saying he'd traced  Mary...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary is Lila's sister?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. He traced her to that motel,  out on the old highway...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the Sheriff)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bates' Motel. (to Lila)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He has a mind like a mechanical brain  and the more information you feed  it... Go on, Sam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He traced her there and called us to  say he was going to question Mrs.  Bates...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a pleasant shock)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norman took a wife?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. An old woman, his mother. (to Sheriff, quickly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was early this evening. And we  haven't seen or heard from him since.   I went out to the motel, just got  back. No one was in the office, and...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupting,  anxiously)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you help us? I think something's  wrong out there!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a considerate  pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now. Your sister is missing how long?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She left Phoenix a week ago yesterday.  And no trace until...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How'd you and this detective come to  trace her to Fairvale?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They thought she'd be coming to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Left Phoenix under her own steam?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She ain't missing so much as she's  run away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a look at sam, then:)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She stole some money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A lot?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forty thousand dollars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the police haven't been able  to...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupting)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone concerned thought... if  they could get her to give back the  money... they could avoid involving  her with the police.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Explains the private detective. He  traced her to the Bates place.  What'd  he exactly say when he called you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary had been there, one night, and  had left.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With the forty thousand dollars?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He didn't mention the money. (anxiously)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What he said on the phone isn't  important, is it?  He was supposed  to come back after he spoke to the  mother, and he didn't! That's what I  want you to do something about!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go out there! Find somebody, ask  some questions! (a pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry if I seem over-anxious to  you. I keep thinking... something's  wrong. I have to know what!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think something's wrong, too, Miss.  But not the same thing. I think your  private detective is what's wrong. (As Lila is about to  object)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think he got himself a hot lead as  to where your sister was going...  probably from Norman Bates...  and  called you to keep you still while  he took off after her and the money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He said he was dissatisfied... and  was going back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Sheriff)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you call Norman and let  him say just what happened, if he  give the man a hot lead and he did  just scooted off... it'll make the  girl feel better, Albert.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At this hour?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was out when I was there. If he's  back he probably isn't even in bed  yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He wasn't out when you were there.   He just wasn't answering the door in  the dead of night... like some people  do. This fellow lives like a hermit...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Recluse. Kinder word.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Sam)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must remember that bad business  out there. About ten years ago...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've only been here five. Right now  it feels like ten, but...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right! Then call! At least, call! Mrs. Chambers goes to phone, dials operator.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Florrie, the Sheriff wants you to  connect him with the Bates Motel. She hands the receiver to the Sheriff. He takes it,  reluctantly, listens to the dim sound of RINGING on the o end. After a moment:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norman? Sheriff Chambers. (listens)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Been just fine, thanks. Listen, we  got some worries here. Did you have  a man stop out there tonight... (listens)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, this one wouldn't be a customer,  anyway. A private detective, name  of...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arbogast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arbogast. (listens)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And after he left? (listens)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, it's okay, Norman. How's it been  going out there? (listens)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I think you oughta unload that  place and open up closer in to the  action, a smaller place, you know...  but...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry I got you up, boy. Go back to  sleep. Yeah, be glad to. (hangs up, turns to  Mrs. Chambers)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Said to give you his regards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (faint irony)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was that all?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This detective was out there and  Norman told him about the girl and  the detective thanked him and went  away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And he didn't go back? Didn't see  the mother? The Sheriff looks long at Lila, shakes his head  sympathetically.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should've called in the police  the second you found your sister has  skipped. You go starting private  investigations, using people you  don't even know...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What difference does that...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your Detective told you a nakedfaced  lie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barefaced.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He told you he wasn't coming right  back cause he wanted to question  Norman Bates' mother, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a pause, then calmly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norman Bates' mother has been dead  and buried in Greenlawn Cemetery for  the last ten years! There is a long silence. Sam and Lila stare at the Sherif

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I helped Norman pick out the dress  she was buried in. Periwinkle blue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It ain't only local history, Sam,  it's the only murder-and-suicide  case in Fairvale ledgers! Mrs. Bates poisoned this guy she was...  involved with, when she found out he  was married, then took a helping of  the same stuff herself.  Strychnine.  Ugly way to die.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norman found them dead together.  In  bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean that old woman I saw sittin'  in the window wasn't Norman Bates'  mother?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hopefully, happily)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe you saw Mary!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd know the difference between Mary  and an old woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now wait a minute, Sam. You sure you  saw an old woman?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes! In the house behind the motel.  I pounded and called but she... just  ignored me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you want to tell me you saw Norman  Bates' mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It must've been. Arbogast said so,  too... and he said the young man  wouldn't let him see her because she  was ill! The Sheriff stares at both of them, and when he finally s there is an almost inaudible tone or irony in his voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, if the woman up there is Mrs. Bates... who's that woman buried out  at Greenlawn Cemetery?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norman sits in the dim, one-lamp light, the phone next to him, his hand still near it as if he had not been able to move his hand after hanging up. He is staring at the shri like bird which is perched on the lamp shade. Decision an resolution are beginning to show in his face. Suddenly he rises, starts quickly out of the room, tries to switch of the lamp as he goes and in so doing succeeds only in knoc the bird off the shade. He watches it fall, does not try to catch it. It hits the floor with a thud and sawdust spills out. He stares sadly it, for a moment, then tends down, scoops up the sawdust, tries to press it into the split seam, picks up the bird, puts it in a drawer. Then he puts out the lamp, goes out, crosses the darkened office and goes outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norman comes off the porch, walks to the path and directl up to the house, opens the door and goes in.

dialogues.speaker: SHOOTING UP THE STAIRS
dialogues.text: Norman goes up, pauses one moment outside his mother's do then opens it and goes in, leaving the door open. For a moment we hear only Norman's low, quiet voice, his  words indistinguishable. Then we hear the cold shot of hi mother's derisive laughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am sorry, boy, but you do manage  to look ludicrous when you give me  orders!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, mother...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Sharp, laughter all  gone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! I will not hide in the fruit  cellar! (A shrill laugh)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Think I'm fruity, huh? (Hard, cold again)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm staying right here!  This is my  room and no one will drag me out of  it... least of all my big bold son!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Rising now, anxiously)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They'll come now, Mother. He came  after the girl and now someone will  come after him! How long do you think  you can go on... Mother, please,  just for a few days, just so they  won't find you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Mimicking)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just for a few days... (Furious)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In that dank fruit cellar? No!  You  hid me there once, boy, and you won't  do it again! Not ever again!  Now  get out! (A pause, quiet)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told you to get out, boy! (A longer pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norman! What do you think you're  going to do? Don't you touch me! Don't! Norman! (A pause, then  cajolingly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, son, put me down and I'll  go. I'll go on my own two feet. I  can go on my own two feet, can't I? During all this the CAMERA has been slowly creeping up th stairs. It does not stop at the top however, but continue on the same high angle that we had in Scene 57. She starts to laugh, a terrible sound like an obscene mel

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll carry you, mother. Norman comes out of the room, his mother held in his arms her head leaning against his shoulder. He carries her dow the stairs, along the lower landing to the cellar stairs, and then down those stairs to the basement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An overcast morning, but a sunny-faced crowd. The service just over, there is contentment, and peace, and just a li I-went-to-church-smugness in the faces of the churchgoers they come out of the chapel, and spread their separate wa away. Amongst the crowd, waiting and searching the faces, are S and Lila. In their expressions there is no peace, no  contentment. CAMERA MOVES IN CLOSE. They are not speaking Lila looks as if she has had no sleep. Suddenly, Sam becomes alert, takes Lila's arm, starts tow the church. CAMERA MOVES WITH THEM, stops as they approach Sheriff an Mrs. Chambers. The Sheriff stares rather sympathetically Lila. Mrs. Chambers smiles nicely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We thought, if you didn't mind, we'd  go out to the motel with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's already been.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Went out before service.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you two had breakfast?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (To Sheriff, not a  question)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You didn't find anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing. Here, let's clear the path. He moves away and the others follow. CAMERA PANS them to curb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Interrupting)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did he say anything about my sister?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just what he told your detective. She used a fake name, saw the register myself. Saw the wh place, as a matter of fact. That boy is alone there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must've seen an illusion, Sam. Now, I know you're not the seeing- illusion type... But no woman was  illusion there and I don't believe  in ghosts, so there it is!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I still feel...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can see you do. Sorry I couldn't  make you feel better. You want to  come to my office this afternoon and  report a missing person... And the  theft, is what you want to do!  Sooner  you drop this thing in the lap of  the law, that's the sooner you'll  stand a chance of your sister bein'  picked up. How about that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Sunday. Come over and do the  reporting at the house, 'round dinner  time. Make it nicer. You too, Sam. She smiles brightly, as if having invited them over to di this year's charity fandango, takes the Sheriff's arm, starts away. The Sheriff nods as he goes. Sam and Lila are alone now, at the curb, before the deser chapel. For a long moment they just stand there, their fa as gray and overcast as the sky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe I am the seeing-illusions type.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not. Sam takes her arm, starts walking her up the street towar the spot where his pick-up truck is parked. CAMERA FOLLOWS them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Want me to drop you at the hotel?   Or you want to come over to the store? Lila does not answer. They reach the truck. Lila looks  directly at Sam as he helps her into the cab.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I won't feel satisfied unless I got  out there, Sam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neither will I. He slams the door, hurries around truck, gets into driver seat, starts motor. As the truck drives off,

dialogues.speaker: SAM AND LILA IN TRUCK
dialogues.text: For a moment, both are silent; Sam watching the road as i there were other cars on it, Lila staring at nothing in  particular, except perhaps her own inner fear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wonder if we'll ever see Mary again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course we will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alive. Sam looks as if he'd like to say something humorous, some to cheer her. He cannot. He remains silent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We lived together all our lives. When we woke up one morning and found ourselves orphans,  Mary quit college and got a job, so I could go to college

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where'd you go to college?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't. I got a job, too. (A pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wonder if that hurt her, my not  letting her sacrifice for me?  Some  people are so willing to suffer for  you that they suffer more if you  don't let them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Almost to himself)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She was willing to lick the stamps. Lila looks quizzically at him, is too concerned to pursue it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wonder so many things about her  now.  Why she never told me about  you...  Funny, when you think there's  an answer to everything, you think  you know all the answers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We were going to get married. Are  going to get married!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know how I found out about  you? I found one of your letters...  it was a nice letter, Sam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is the old highway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I suppose... when you were able to  marry her she'd have presented you,  all shiny and proper... she always  tried to be proper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watch your tenses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She always tries to be proper. Sam slows the truck to a stop, sighs, starts to light up cigarette. Lila looks questioningly and impatiently at hi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You going to wait here for me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going with you. But we'd better  decide what we're going to say and  do when we walk in...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're going to register. As man and  wife. And get shown to a cabin...  and then search every inch of that  place, inside and... outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You won't believe it... (Starts motor)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But this will be the first time I've ever pulled one of those man- and-wife-renting-cabin capers!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (A tiny smile, first  in hours)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I believe it. As truck starts to drive on,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The place is empty and silent and washed dirty by the dee gray of the cloudy sky. We see Sam's truck turning into t driveway and pulling to a stop. After a moment, Sam and L get out of the truck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Close on Sam and Lila as they meet on the porch side of t truck. The motel office and the house beyond can be seen b.g. of shot. Sam and Lila merely stare for a moment, the turn and gaze up at the house. There is no figure in the  window and the shade is drawn. Same goes to the office do peers in, knocks, opens door, enters. Lila remains on the driveway, beside the truck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ANGLE on Norman standing by the window. He has pull the curtains very slightly apart, is staring out and down the motel, his eyes studying the lone figure of Lila, who standing by the truck and looking up at the house.  Norma studies her, and as her eyes look up at this very window closes the curtains, turns away. We see the suspicion and fear in his face, the surge of p and his struggle to contain it. Then he goes away. CAMERA remains on window, shooting out and down, and through the frail curtains we can see Sam as he comes out of the mote office and joins Lila.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Unconsciously  whispering)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wonder where Norman Bates does his  hermiting?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Someone was at that window. I saw  the curtain move. Sam takes Lila's arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on. He starts with her toward the path which leads to the old house. CAMERA PANS with them, and as they turn around the office corner, they see Norman coming down the path towar them. They pause and Norman pauses. He does not smile, no speak. His usual grin and soft friendliness are gone;  containment and impassivity lie in their place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Cheerfully)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just coming up to ring for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Coming forward)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I suppose you want a cabin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'd hoped to make it straight to  San Francisco, but we don't like the  look of that sky. Looks like a bad  day coming... doesn't it. Norman walks past Sam, giving him the sort of quick,  disapproving glance one gives a man who is obviously lyin goes onto the porch and into the office. Sam and Lila fol Norman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norman crosses to the desk, goes behind it, takes the key cabin number twelve off the keyboard. Sam and Lila have  entered and are almost to the desk-counter by this time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll take you to...
