dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Better sign in first, hasn't we? Sam eyes scan the counter, looking for a registration boo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It isn't necessary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Interrupting with a  friendly cheerfulness)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh, uh! My boss is paying for this  trip... ninety percent business...  and he wants practically notarized  receipts. I better sign in and get a  receipt. Norman stares at Sam, as if he'd like to yell at him, cal him "liar." Instead he reaches under the desk counter, br out the registration book. Lila moves closer, studies the book as Sam signs in. Sam signs "Joe and Mrs. Johnson." signature and city of "Marie Samuels" and after it, the  notation "Cabin One," can be clearly seen three registrat above Sam's. When Sam has finished he closes book, hands it back to No Norman does not take it, starts out from behind counter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll get your bags.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haven't any.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a stare)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll show you the cabin. As he starts for the door, Sam laughs. Norman stops, turn looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First time I've seen it happen. (to Lila)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Check in any place in this country  without bags, and you have to pay in  advance. Sam smiles as if at a funny remark, takes a bill out of h pocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ten dollars... Norman returns to Sam, takes the extended bill, is about start out again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That receipt...? Norman goes reluctantly behind counter, lays down the key cabin twelve, takes a receipt book out of the drawer unde counter, starts to write. Lila steps up to the desk, pick up the key, quickly, starts out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll start ahead. Norman looks up, gazes her as she goes out door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lila comes along the porch, pauses before cabin one, trie the door. It opens. She closes it quickly as she hears Sa and Norman coming out of the motel office, continues on d the porch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (To Norman, who is  following)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't bother yourself... we'll find  it. He goes on down the porch, doesn't even glance at cabin o walks quickly and catches up to Lila just as she reaches  cabin twelve. CAMERA REMAINS with Norman, who is standing the office door, looking after Sam and Lila, his face ale and no longer impassive. He waits a moment, after they ha closed their cabin door, then crosses to the pickup truck CAMERA MOVES with him. He studies the truck, then leans i through the driver's window, twists the registration card around, reads it. It gives the correct name and address of Sam Loomis. Norman comes back out of the window, glances once more to cabin twelve, then at the old house. His suspicions are  confirmed, and now there is the relaxation of relief in h face. He takes on a purposeful air, turns, strides up the path, up onto the porch of the house, opens the door, goe in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lila is at the cabin's rear window, looking out, strainin for a glimpse of the old house, which cannot be seen from the window of this cabin. She turns, frustrated, anxious. Sam is standing at the fo of the bed, staring at the smooth coverlet, his brow crea in a sadness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We should have asked for Cabin One...  The one Mary was in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm glad we didn't. He pulls his eyes from the bed, crosses to the desk, sits wearily, lights a cigarette. Lila watches him for a momen feels a real compassion, goes to the bed, sits on its edg turns again and looks at Sam's back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have to go into that cabin and  search it, Sam... no matter what  we're afraid of finding and no matter  how much it may hurt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. (A pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you think if something happened,  it happened there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (A pause, then:)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam, if you owned a useless business  like this motel... one you probably  couldn't even sell...  what would  you need to get away, to start a new  business, somewhere else? (As Sam studies her)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forty thousand dollars?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How could we prove... (An almost hopeless  laugh)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, if he opens a new motel on the  new highway... say, a year from now...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There must be some proof that exists  right now! Something that proves he  got that money away from Mary...  Some way!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What makes you sound so certain?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arbogast! Sam, he liked me... or  felt sorry for me... and he was  starting to feel the same about you.  I heard it when he called... in his  voice, a caring. He wouldn't have  gone anywhere or done anything without  telling us.  Unless he was stopped.  And he was stopped, so he must have  found out something! Sam considers a moment, nods agreement, rises.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll start with Cabin One. He goes to the door, opens it slightly, looks out, then,  back to Lila:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If he sees us... we're just taking  the air. Lila goes to the door. He holds it open and she goes out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam closes the door, joins Lila, takes her hand. Together they walk along the porch in the direction of Ca One. CAMERA FOLLOWS. They pause before the door of Cabin  One. Sam motions Lila to wait, to hold still, then goes o to the office, opens the door, calls in:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bates? He waits, there is no response. He goes in and in a momen comes back out, closes the door, goes to Lila. She has already opened the door of Cabin One and has star to enter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The blinds are closed and the room is almost night-dark. Sam comes in after Lila, closes the door behind him. For a moment they just gaze at the room, as if willing it tell them some satisfactory story. Neither speaks. Then, in dark silence, they begin to sear going methodically and thoroughly through all drawers, th closet, the desk, searching under the bed and in dark cor not knowing what they expect to find and yet expecting to find some thing. Lila opens the bathroom door, looks in. windowless room is very dark. She switches on the light,  goes in. Sam moves toward the bathroom, is about to follo her in when he notices which room it is and automatically catches himself up, backs out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hospital clean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bathroom. Look at how clean it  is. The one in our cabin is clean...  but this is clean! Sam goes in, glances around, nods. Lila goes through the  medicine cabinet, finds nothing but a glass and two tiny  tabs of soap. Sam leans against the door-jamb, looks at t tub, the shower pipe above it. He continues to stare, mor interested suddenly, as if bothered by some off-key evide he can't put his finger on. Then he looks at the shower  curtain rod. And realizes there is no shower curtain. He frowns, is ab to say something when Lila, who has been momentarily out shot, interrupts. Sam turns, CAMERA TURNS, and we see Lila is standing abov the toilet bowl, a tiny piece of wet paper stuck to the t of her right index finger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It didn't get washed down. It's  figuring... the kind you tear up and  get rid of. (Extending her finger  toward Sam)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some figure has been added to or  subtracted from... forty thousand. Sam lifts the piece of paper off her finger, studies it,  takes out his wallet, presses the wet scrap to his driver license shield, puts it back in the wallet and puts the w away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's proof Mary was here!  It would  be too wild a coincidence for somebody  else to...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Reminding)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bates never denied Mary was here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Reminded)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. (A thought)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But maybe this proves that Bates  found out about the money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do we simply ask him where he's hidden  it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam, that old woman, whoever she is.  I think she told Arbogast something!  And I want her to tell us the same  thing! She starts out of the bathroom. Sam takes hold of her arm stops her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't go up there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bates. CAMERA STARTS TO PAN AWAY from them, moves slowly over th room, very slowly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's find him. One of us can keep  him occupied while the other gets to  the woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You won't be able to hold him still  if he doesn't want to be held. And I  don't like you going into that house  alone, Lila. CAMERA HAS PANNED clear across to the opposite wall now, is moving up closer and closer to the tiny-flowered wall  paper, finally closing in on one small rosebud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can handle a sick old woman. Now we see that the rosebud has been cut out, that this i the reverse side of the hole Norman peeped through to wat Mary. And we see the pupil of Norman's eye now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right. I'll find Bates and keep  him occupied. The eye moves away and there is a brief flash of light be the hole is covered, on the other side, by the wall-hung  painting.

dialogues.speaker: LILA AND SAM
dialogues.text: They are about to start out. Sam stops her again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait a minute. If you get anything  out of the mother... (A thought)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you find your way back to town? (As Lila nods yes)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you do get anything, don't stop  to tell me. Lila nods quickly, hurries to the door. Sam gets to it fi opens it a slight crack, looks out, then opens it wide en for Lila and Himself to pass through.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGLE CLOSE on cabin one as Lila comes out, turns to her  left, goes along porch toward cabin twelve. Sam remains a the door, then turns right, heading for the path. As he p the office, he is shocked to see Norman standing just ins the open door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looking for me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Recovering)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, matter of fact. (The friendly grin)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The wife's taking a nap and... I can  never keep quiet enough for her...  so I thought I'd look you up and...  talk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Satisfied with your cabin?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine. Sam starts into the office. Just before going in, he glan down the long porch, sees Lila standing outside the door cabin twelve, waves her a tiny "all clear" signal.

dialogues.speaker: LILA
dialogues.text: CAMERA ANGLES to include Lila and her point of view. She watches Sam disappear into the office, waits until sh hears the door close, then looks about for another way to reach the house. She sees the small alley at the end of t L of cabins, starts toward it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Behind the motel Lila hesitates. She looks ahead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The old house standing against the sky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lila moves forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CAMERA approaching the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lila glances toward the back of Norman's parlor. She move on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The house coming nearer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lila looks up at the house. She moves forward purposefull

dialogues.speaker: S.L.S.
dialogues.text: The house and the porch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lila stops at the house and looks up. She glances back. She turns to the house again.

dialogues.speaker: S.L.S.
dialogues.text: The CAMERA MOUNTS the steps to the porch.

dialogues.speaker: C.U.
dialogues.text: Lila puts out her hand.

dialogues.speaker: S.C.U.
dialogues.text: Lila's hand pushes the door open. We see the hallway. Lila ENTERS PAST CAMERA.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lila closes the door, remains by it for a moment, quiet,  listening. Her eyes scan the layout, the closed door whic leads off the hallway, to the dining room on the right an the parlor on the left. Down at the end of the hall is th kitchen, the door wide open, the room beyond dim and sile She notices the stairs leading down to the basement, star at them, then back to the stairs leading to the second fl She starts forward, and seems about to investigate the pa and dining room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norman is behind the counter, standing, staring at Sam wh is sitting relaxedly on a small sofa. Norman has the look one who is protecting himself, as if the counter were a  protective wall against the threatening world across it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Cheerfully, as if  after a self-conscious  pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been doing all the talking so  far, haven't I?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I always thought it was the people  who are alone so much who do all the  talking when they get the chance.  Yet there you are, doing all the  listening! (A pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are alone here, aren't you? (As Norman does not  reply)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It would drive me crazy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That would be a rather extreme  reaction, wouldn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Lightly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just an expression... (More seriously)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What I meant was... I'd do just about  anything... to get away.  Wouldn't  you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lila is halfway up the stairs. As she climbs she is start by the creaks and groans of the old wood of the steps. Sh steps more carefully. CAMERA remains at foot of stair, TI UP as Lila climbs. She pauses at the head of the stair. T door on her right, which opens into the mother's room, is closed. To her left is another door, half-open. Directly  before her is a third door, closed. She holds a long mome trying to picture in her mind which room would look out o the front of the house, decides, chooses the correct door the one on her right. She goes to it, knocks lightly.

dialogues.speaker: DOOR
dialogues.text: We hear Lila's second knock, then, faintly, her soft call

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Bates? There is quiet for a moment, then the door begins to open and we see Lila. She stands on the threshold, looking in the room, instantly disturbed by it, almost chilled, her  expression indicating an impulse to close the door and go away from this room forever. After a moment, she enters, leaving the door open behind  her. CAMERA PULLS BACK AND AWAY and we now see the room a Lila sees it. It is ornate, damask-and-mahogany, thick and warm and rip an olla podrida of mismated furnishings and bric-a-brac o the last century. The bed is four poster, but uncanoped; dressing table is fancy and flounced with satin; there is great chiffonier, a big-doored wardrobe, a large, oval, f length pier-glass (this against the wall directly opposit the door), a satin recamier, an upholstered armchair by t window, a white marble fireplace, its grate cold but pile with ashes. And there is in the room an unmistakably live quality, as even though it is presently unoccupied, it has not been l vacated by some musty presence. Lila glances at the bed. The damask coverlet is thrown ov it, but it is not neat, there is the imprint of a body on it, a body which obviously has slept in a curled-up, womb like position. Lila stares at it for a moment, up, then g to the dressing table. Its top is scattered with boxes an jars of cosmetics and creams, traces of fresh powder, an  opened bottle or perfume, a comb, and a brush with traces hair in its bristles. Lila moves on, catches a glimpse of herself in the pier-glass, is startled, turns away, goes the chiffonier, is about to open a drawer, sees the high  wardrobe out of the corner of her eyes, goes to it,  hesitantly. She opens one door. Fresh, clean, well presse dresses hang neatly. Lila opens the other door. The sweat and dresses and robes hang freely, none in moth-proof, st type bags. There is even a well-brushed collar of foxes. Along the floor of the wardrobe is a line of clean, polis shoes. Lila stares, then closes the door, turns, looks on again over the whole room, starts out,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lila comes out of the mother's room, closes the door behi her, looks down the stairs, then starts across the hall t the room whose door is half-open. The room within is dark the shades drawn full. Lila pauses on the threshold, reaches in, feels the wall, throws on a switch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam has risen, is standing by the counter now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not saying you shouldn't be  contented here, I'm just doubting  that you are. I think if you saw a  chance to get out from under...   you'd unload this place...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Angrily)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This place! This isn't 'a place.'   It's my only world. I grew up in  that house back there. I was a happy  child. My mother and I... we were  more than happy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And now that your mother's dead? Norman snaps a sharp, fast, ugly look at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My mother is not dead!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Softly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't think so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lila is standing in the doorway, staring at the room in s dismay. The room is grotesque, a horrible, ludicrous fant of childhood held beyond the point of decency. It is a small room. The walls are fancied with romping  silhouettes of teddy-bears and sailboats and carousels an fat cows jumping over aghast moons. The bed is small, far too short for a man of Norman's height. And yet the rumpl covers indicate that it is in this bed that Norman sleeps Next to the bed is an old-fashioned toy chest. On its top there are a bird-in-a-cage lamp, a plain-bound book, and ash tray filled with ashes and cigarette stubs. A grown m shirt hangs on a child's clothes tree. Against one wall there is a narrow, high bookcase filled  with thick, unchildish-looking books. On the small, white chest of drawers there is an old, child's victrola. The r on the turntable is discovered, on close inspection, to b Beethoven's Eroica Symphony. Lila studies the room, fascinated and repelled. She glanc at the bookcase, comes into the room, goes to the bookcas and pulls out a thick, large, plain-bound book. She opens it. Her eyes go wide in shock. And then there is disgust. She slams the book closed, drops it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norman, behind the counter, has moved back against the wa Sam is still on the other side of the counter, but is lea forward, his eyes hard on Norman's face. Norman's face is no longer expressionless. It has the sta high sheen of a cornered animal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Pressing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You look frightened. Have I been  saying something frightening?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know what you've been saying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been talking about your mother...  about your motel. How are you going  to do it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Buy a new one! In a new town! Where you won't have to hide your  mother!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut up!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where will you get the money to do  that, Bates... or do you already  have it... socked away... a lot of  it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leave me alone!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Forty thousand dollars!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leave me alone! He is close to panic now. He turns, swiftly, dashes back  into his private parlor. Sam goes quickly around the coun follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norman hears Sam following, wants to run, to never be rea by this man. He crosses the small room, drawn to the rear window, as if he might fly through it. Sam enters, pauses Norman turns, back against the window, as unable to fly a as are the many still, stuffed birds. Sam registers a bri flicker of reaction when he sees the birds, but continues gaze at Norman, hard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I bet your mother knows where the  money is. And what you did to get  it. And I think she'll tell us. Something self-assured and confident in Sam's tone gives  Norman a new, more terrified alarm. He turns his head, gl out the window at the old house. He looks back at Sam and there is terror in his voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's that girl? The girl you came  with! Where is she? Sam does not respond, smiles a half-smile, turns to exami a stuffed owl. Norman looks back at the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (A horrible groan)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, God!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lila, shaken and disturbed, almost sickened, is coming ou of Norman's room. She has left the light on. She pauses i the middle of the landing, looks at the closed door oppos the stairs, goes to it, opens it, sees that it is the  bathroom, pulls the door to, turns, starts toward the sta

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam is lying on the floor, face downward, unmoving. A  candlestick is on the floor, close by his head, still roc as if just dropped. OVER SHOT comes the SOUND of Norman's footsteps and CAMERA TURNS in time to catch a brief glimp of him going out into the office, almost at a run.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lila is on the top step, looking down toward CAMERA. She is listening, hoping to hear some human sound, some s she might follow, pursue. She hears nothing. She starts d the stairs. Just below the halfway step, she looks at the front door, sees out through the door window:

dialogues.speaker: LILA'S VIEWPOINT
dialogues.text: Norman coming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For a moment Lila panics, then she hurries down the steps cannot go in the direction of the front door, remembers t stairway behind her, turns and runs in that direction. Th SOUND of Norman bounding up the porch steps can be heard. Lila turns and dashes down the stairs which lead to the  basement, going down far enough to conceal herself, crouc there. Norman enters the hallway, closes the door softly, listen He glances once in the direction of the basement stairs. seems about to smile, when suddenly all expression vanish from his face, and he appears to enter a no-place, no-tim state. He crosses to the stairway, goes up. Lila remains crouched on the basement stairs, listening t the SOUNDS of Norman. His footsteps on the stairs followe by the fast noises of doors opening, of fast moving about upstairs room. Convinced that he is searching the upstair for her, she decides to chance an escape. She starts up t steps, is about to turn into the hallway when her eye is  caught by a glimmer of light down in the basement. She pa looks down, sees the crack of light coming from behind th not entirely closed door to the fruit cellar. The swift m SOUNDS of Norman continue to come from upstairs. Lila is torn, knows she should get out of the house while she has the chance, is unable to resist the impulse to ch that hidden-looking room down below, a room in which, she desperately believes, there must lie some answer to what  happened to Mary. She turns and goes softly and quickly d the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lila reaches the bottom, stops, listens, hears the stairb creaking as footsteps fall hard and measured upon them. S turns, pulls open the fruit cellar door, looks in. The wo is sitting in a comfortable chair, the back of the chair, and the woman, turned to the door. Lila calls a harsh,  frightened whisper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Bates...? Lila goes into the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lila goes to the chair, touches it. The touch disturbs th figure. It starts to turn, slowly, stiffly, a clock-wise  movement. Lila looks at it in horror. It is the body of a woman long dead. The skin is dry and pulled away from the mouth and the teeth are revealed as in the skeleton's smi The eyes are gone from their sockets, the bridge of the n has collapsed, the hair is dry and wild, the cheeks are  sunken, the leathery-brown skin is powdered and rouged an flaky. The body is dressed in a high-neck, clean, well-pr dress, obviously recently laundered and hand-ironed. The movement of this stuffed, ill-preserved cadaver, turn as if in response to Lila's call and touch, is actually  graceful, ballet-like, and the effect is terrible and obs Lila gazes for one flicker of a deathly moment, then begi to scream, a high, piercing, dreadful scream. And Lila's scream is joined by another scream, a more  dreadful, horrifying scream which comes from the door beh her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (screaming)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ayeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeee Am Norma  Bates! Lila turns.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: His face is contorted. He wears a wild wig, a mockery of woman's hair. He is dressed in a high-neck dress which is similar to that worn by the corpse of his mother. His han is raised high, poised to strike at Lila. There is a long breadknife in it.

dialogues.speaker: LILA
dialogues.text: Close on her face. She is dumb-struck. Her eyes are screa

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO NORMAN
dialogues.text: As he is about to start forward, a man's hand reaches in  from the doorway behind, grabs Norman's wrist. Sam comes  through the door, still holding tight to the wrist, pulli back the arm and at the same time throwing himself at Nor football tackle style.

dialogues.speaker: THE FIGHT
dialogues.text: Norman and Sam, struggling. The wild fury in Norman's fac the mad noise of his screams and vile curses. The terrifi fight-to-the-death look of Sam. The still, staring Lila.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. BATES
dialogues.text: A close of her face, She appears to be watching and enjoy the fight. Over the shot, the SOUNDS of the struggle, the screams of Norman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are many people gathered about the steps, the curio and the concerned and the morbid. At the curb, a couple o newspaper cars, two or three police cars, and a mobile un truck from the local television outlet. There is noise, a chattering as questions are asked and answers given, and sounds of traffic, and of the television equipment being  moved into the courthouse, for on-the-scene reporting, an the stern voices of policemen trying to keep people back. The scene has a bright glare about it, that quality of su light thrown on a fearful darkness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A POLICEMAN trying to make way for the television men,  muttering "keep back," etc., to the spectators. A TELEVIS MAN, carrying a piece of equipment goes through door, and CAMERA FOLLOWS him into the courthouse vestibule. Here, too, there is a crowd, composed of Policemen, Repor Television Men. The Television Men we have been following stops beside a Policeman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Indicating the front  door he has just  come in through)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think they'll take him out that  way?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Looking at waiting  crowd, shrugging)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Probably have to. (A rueful smile)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Besides, the taxpayers hate it when  something gets slipped out the back  door on them! Over this exchange, the buzz of other voices, the movemen of men. CAMERA MOVES ON, down the corridor, gets to the d of the office of the Chief of Police just as a young fell with a carton box filled with paper containers of sent-ou for coffee reaches this door. CAMERA HOLDS as the COFFEE pauses a moment, then goes into the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lila is seated in a chair, Sam standing close by. A bit a from them, we see Sheriff Chambers, in quiet conference w the CHIEF OF POLICE, the COUNTY SHERIFF, the DISTRICT  ATTORNEY. The Coffee Boy stands in the doorway. Sam goes to him, ta a container of coffee from the box, carries it to Lila,  checking the notation on the lid as he goes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's regular. Okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (ruefully)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I could stand something regular. Sam smiles encouragingly, hands her the coffee. Sheriff  Chambers ENTERS SHOT, gives Sam a container of coffee he brought for him. Sam takes it, nods a thank you. For a moment no one speaks. Lila looks badly shaken, Sam  disheveled, but contained.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You two can go on home if you like. (a sympathetic look  at Lila)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Making that statement was enough for  one night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Lila)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Want to?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I'm all right. I'll feel better  when all this is explained... if it  can be. Sam looks a question at Sheriff Chambers. Chambers shrugs doubtfully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If anybody gets any answers, it'll  be the fellow talking to him now...  the Psychiatrist. Even I couldn't  reach Norman... and he knows me. (to Lila)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You warm enough, Miss? Lila is about to answer, when she sees someone come into room and rises anxiously. Sam and Sheriff Chambers turn,  follow her gaze.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A young man with a serious, frowning face has just come i the room. He is DR. SIMON, the Psychiatrist. He goes to the desk where the box of coffee containers ha been placed, takes up a container.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did he talk to you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I got the whole story... but not  from Norman. I got it from... his  mother. Everyone gazes at him, mystified. He speaks as he removes lid from coffee container.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norman Bates no longer exists. He  only half-existed to begin with...   now, the other half has taken over.   Probably for all time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (With difficulty)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did he kill my sister?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes... and no.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, if you're trying to lay a lot  of psychiatric groundwork for some  sort of plea this fellow would like  to cop...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A psychiatrist doesn't lay the  groundwork .. he merely tries to  explain it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But my sister is...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. I'm sorry. (to Chambers)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Private Investigator, too. If  you drag that swamp somewhere in the  vicinity of the motel... (To the Chief of Police)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you any unsolved missing persons  cases on your books?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Two.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Young girls?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nods, astounded,  then:)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did he confess to...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupting)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As I said, the mother... (Pauses, goes on afresh)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To understand it, as I understood it  hearing it from the mother...  That  is, from the mother-half of Norman's  mind, you have to go back ten years...  to the time when Norman murdered his  mother and her lover. (A pause, then as no  one interrupts)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was already dangerously disturbed,  had been ever since his father died.  His mother was a clinging, demanding  woman... and for years the two of  them lived as if there was no one  else in the world. Then she met a  man and it seemed to Norman she "threw  him over" for this man. That pushed  him over the thin line... and he  killed them both. Matricide is  probably the most unbearable crime  of all... and most unbearable to the  son who commit it. So he had to erase  the crime, at least in his own mind. (A pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stole her corpse... and a weighted  coffin was buried. He hid the body  in the fruit cellar, even "treated"  it to keep it as well as it would  keep. And that still wasn't enough.  She was there, but she was a corpse.   So he began to think and speak for  her, gave her half his life, so to  speak. At times he could be both  personalities, carry on  conversations... at other times, the  mother-half took over completely. He  was never all Norman, but he was  often only mother. And because he  was so pathologically jealous of  her, he assumed she was as jealous  of him. Therefore, if he felt a strong  attraction to any other woman, the  mother side of him would go wild. (To Lila)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When Norman met your sister, he was  touched by her... and aroused by  her. He wanted her. And this set off  his "jealous mother" and...  "mother  killed the girl." After the murder,  Norman returned as if from a deep  sleep... and like a dutiful son,  covered up all traces of the crime  he was convinced his mother had  committed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why was he... dressed like that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's a transvestite!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not exactly. A man who dresses in  woman's clothing in order to achieve  a sexual change... or satisfaction...  is a transvestite.  But in Norman's  case, he was simply doing everything  possible to keep alive the illusion  of his mother being alive. And  whenever reality came too close,  when danger or desire threatened  that illusion, he'd dress up, even  to a cheap wig he brought, and he'd  walk about the house, sit in her  chair, speak in her voice... He tried  to be his mother. (A sad smile)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And now he is. (A pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what I meant when I said I  got the story from the mother. She  thinks Norman has been taken away...  because of his crimes.  She insists  she did nothing, that Norman committed  all the murders just to keep her  from being discovered. She even smiled  a bit coquettishly as she said that.  Of course, she feels badly about  it... but also somewhat relieved to  be, as she put it, free of Norman,  at last. (A pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When the mind houses two  personalities, there is always a  battle. In Norman's case, the battle  is over... and the dominant  personality has won. Lila begins to weep softly, for Mary, for Arbogast, for  Norman, for all the destroyed human beings of this world. Sam bends beside her, puts his arm about her, comforts he

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (To Simon)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the forty thousand dollars?  Who  got that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The swamp. These were murders of  passion, not profit. A POLICE GUARD puts his head in the door, speaks, in a ne whisper, to the Chief of Police. The Guard is carrying a  folded blanket over his arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He feels a little chill... can I  bring him this blanket? The Chief of Police nods. The Guard goes away, and CAMERA FOLLOWS him out of the room and out into the hallway. Gua moves through the waiting men, heading down the corridor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A narrower corridor in the rear of the building. In f.g. shot, we see a door, the top half of which is wire-covere glass. A GUARD in uniform is posted by the door, looking  reprovingly at the two or three people trying to get a gl into the room. The Police Guard, carrying the blanket, comes down this  corridor, goes to the door. CAMERA MOVES CLOSE. The unifo Guard opens the door, allows the man to go in. Shot is RAKED so that we can not see into the room. After a moment, the Guard comes out and the uniformed Gua closes and locks the door and we

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The walls are white and plain. There is no window. There is no furniture except the straight-back chair in w Norman sits, in the center of the room. The room has a qu of no-whereness, of calm separation from the world. The Police Guard has placed the blanket on Norman's knees Norman, as we come upon him, is lifting the blanket, unfo it. His face, although without makeup and without the  surrounding softness of the wig, has a certain femininity about it, a softness about the mouth and a kind of arch  womanliness about the brows. Calmly, Norman places the blanket about his shoulders, as it were a cashmere shawl. CAMERA REMAINS in a position so that our view of Norman is a FULL ONE. When the shawl is position, and Norman is settled, we HEAR, OVER SHOT, the  voice of his mother, coming from the calm of his thoughts

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's sad... when a mother has to  speak the words that condemn her own  son... but I couldn't allow them to  believe that I would commit murder. (A pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They'll put him away now... as I  should have... years ago. He was  always... bad. And in the end, he  intended to tell them I killed those  girls... and that man. As if I could  do anything except just sit and  stare... like one of his stuffed  birds. (A pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, they know I can't even move a  finger. And I won't. I'll just sit  here and be quiet. Just in case they  do... suspect me. A fly buzzes close, and then continues buzzing and flying about Norman's face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're probably watching me.  Well,  let them. Let them see what kind of  a person I am. (A pause, as the fly  lights on Norman's  hand)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not going to swat that fly. I  hope they are watching. They'll see...  they'll see... and they'll know...  and they'll say... 'why, she wouldn't  even harm a fly...' Norman continues to gaze ahead into nothing.

dialogues.speaker: THE SWAMP
dialogues.text: As END TITLES FADE IN, we see the swamp, the chain of a t truck. The chain is attached to Mary's car. The car is co out of the swamp.
